finding: The intergenic SNP rs569994581, situated near ACVR2A-PABPC1P2 on 2q22.3, was notably associated with SCC development, with particularly strong signals among European ancestry.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: An intergenic variant located on 2q32.1, rs182939337 was associated with SCC susceptibility, contributing to novel findings in lung cancer genetics.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: This SNP associated with adenocarcinoma and was located in ACTR2, with a consistent pattern of influence across populations.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: This SNP was identified in the FinnGen study as meeting the GWAS threshold for IIH with a p-value < 5e-08. It was very rare, observed to have an AF of 2.9e-04 in the healthy Finnish population.
title: The genetics of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH): Integration of population studies and clinical data

finding: This missense variant at the GCKR locus was significantly associated with lipid profiles and other traits, showing links to GI disorders and being genome-wide significant in relation to COVID-19+ diarrhea.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS of diarrhea during acute SARS-CoV2 infection identifies multiple novel loci and contrasting etiological roles of irritable bowel syndrome subtypes

finding: The SNP rs1260326, located at the GCKR locus, explained the majority of associations observed in the PGS_T2D_liver_lipid. Specifically, it accounted for 256 out of 268 protein associations, demonstrating a significant pleiotropic effect on circulating proteins, which underscores its relevance in T2D pathology.
title: Identification of plasma proteomic markers underlying polygenic risk of type 2 diabetes and related comorbidities

finding: In the context of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), the T/T genotype of rs315952 was associated with an increased risk of SLE. The study reported that individuals with the T allele also had a higher likelihood of SLE. The C allele and genotypes C/C, and C/T showed no significant associations with SLE, suggesting a protective effect when at least one C allele was present. Overall, these findings indicated rs315952 as a polymorphism linked to SLE susceptibility.
title: “The Association of the IL-1RA (rs315952) Cytokine Gene Polymorphism and Susceptibility to Systemic Lupus Erythematosus: A Meta-analysis”

finding: The SNP rs1420385 was found to significantly down-regulate the expression of the GAD1 exon (ENSE00003699191.1). This exon-level effect was crucial as GAD1 was linked to alterations in the GABA system, widely observed in schizophrenia, therefore this SNP was implicated in the genetic risk factors associated with schizophrenia.
title: Variant-risk-exon interplay impacts on cortical cell-cell interactions in severe psychiatric disorders

finding: The SNP rs7591091 in the CCDC141 locus appeared most frequently in the decision paths of the siRF fit, indicating its significant role in the context of cardiac hypertrophy and also being part of the epistatic interactions identified.
title: Epistasis regulates genetic control of cardiac hypertrophy

finding: The rs1446585 SNP at the LCT locus on chromosome 2 was identified as a significant finding with a p-value of 1.3e-17. It was notably associated with a peak in associations around the birth year 1941, a period marked by elevated infant mortality rates (IMR) during 'The Blitz.' Analysis revealed a significantly increased frequency of the lactase-persistence-associated allele in counties with high IMR in the 1940 birth cohort (p = 0.043), with frequencies declining in later cohorts.
title: GWAS on Birth Year Infant Mortality Rates Provides New Evidence of Recent Natural Selection

finding: The common missense variant rs35777125-G439R was previously associated with a 0.26 years earlier age at natural menopause (ANM). This variant had a minor allele frequency of 11% but was considered benign. In contrast, rare high-contrast protein-truncating variants (HC-PTVs) in the same gene (ETAA1) were linked to nearly a 10-fold earlier ANM of -2.28 years, with a strong statistical significance indicated by a P-value of 5.30*10^-8.
title: Genetic susceptibility to earlier ovarian ageing increases de novo mutation rate in offspring

finding: FN1:rs140926439-T emerged as a resilient variant, indicating a complex relationship with AD risk.
title: Biobank-scale characterization of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias identifies potential disease-causing variants, risk factors, and genetic modifiers across diverse ancestries

finding: FN1:rs116558455-A was identified as resilient, contributing to the understanding of genetic factors influencing AD.
title: Biobank-scale characterization of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias identifies potential disease-causing variants, risk factors, and genetic modifiers across diverse ancestries

finding: RAB10:rs142787485-G was noted for its resilient characteristics, informing the audience about AD risk factors.
title: Biobank-scale characterization of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias identifies potential disease-causing variants, risk factors, and genetic modifiers across diverse ancestries

finding: The SNP rs11692435 was linked with the protein ACTR1B, which showed significant colocalization with dietary habits and BMI. This indicates that the primary genetic association related to BMI, dietary habits, and protein levels could be largely explained by this single variant.
title: Genetic control of body weight by the human brain proteome

finding: The SNP rs1018218 was associated with the protein ADCY3, which displayed a multi-trait colocalization with a cluster of ten dietary habits. The findings suggested that the genetic association with BMI through ADCY3 was primarily mediated by rs1018218.
title: Genetic control of body weight by the human brain proteome

finding: In 2020, it was found that the SNP rs13010105 was associated with subsites of Laryngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma, suggesting that these subsites were molecularly distinct. This distinction is important in the context of understanding cancer types and could influence treatment approaches.
title: Benchmark Pathology Report Text Corpus with Cancer Type Classification

finding: The SNP rs4664446, located in intron 2 of the CD26/DPP4 gene, showed a highly significant association with glucose AUC during oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) in normoglycemic individuals, with a P value of 1.63×10−7. This finding indicated that CD26/DPP4 gene variants govern postprandial glycemic excursions in individuals without dysmetabolism.
title: Prediabetes Blunts CD26/DPP4 Genetic Control of Postprandial Glycemia and Insulin Secretion

finding: The SNP rs2300757 was significantly associated with C-peptide release responses during the OGTT in normoglycemic individuals, with a P value of 6.86×10−5. This association was particularly noted in the later phases of the postprandial response, suggesting a role for CD26/DPP4 gene in insulin secretion.
title: Prediabetes Blunts CD26/DPP4 Genetic Control of Postprandial Glycemia and Insulin Secretion

finding: rs2909449, located in intron 20, demonstrated a strong nominal association with glucose AUC (P=1.96×10−6) under the additive model. Lower glucose excursions in normoglycemic individuals were correlated with lower C-peptide responses, highlighting the gene's indirect influence on insulin release based on glucose levels.
title: Prediabetes Blunts CD26/DPP4 Genetic Control of Postprandial Glycemia and Insulin Secretion

finding: The SNP rs2268890 in intron 18 was found to have a significant association with glucose AUC (P=2.27×10−6) in normoglycemic subjects. This result contributed to the evidence that variants in the CD26/DPP4 gene region can influence postprandial glucose dynamics.
title: Prediabetes Blunts CD26/DPP4 Genetic Control of Postprandial Glycemia and Insulin Secretion

finding: Intron 8 SNP rs6432708 showed a notable association with glucose AUC, with a P value of 2.87×10−5. This finding further supports the role of CD26/DPP4 gene variants in regulating postprandial glycemia in normoglycemic individuals.
title: Prediabetes Blunts CD26/DPP4 Genetic Control of Postprandial Glycemia and Insulin Secretion

finding: The SNP rs11558990, corresponding to a heterozygous exonic mutation 5144A>G, was identified in the OLA1 gene, resulting in a non-synonymous change from 254Tyr to 254Cys in exon 8. This mutation was associated with heart failure in patients and had previously been implicated in cancer patients, where it correlated with poor prognosis. Predictive analyses indicated that this mutation was deleterious. It was suggested to have a significant negative impact on heart function, similar to other mutations in OLA1, emphasizing its importance in cardiomyopathy.
title: Identification and development of Tetra-ARMS PCR-based screening test for a genetic variant of OLA1 (Tyr254Cys) in the human failing heart

finding: This variant was linked to ACOXL at p=5.93×10−18, a gene previously associated with chronic lymphocytic leukemia, suggesting an unexpected relevance to ERM.
title: Genomewide association study of epiretinal membrane: discovery of significant risk loci in each of three American populations

finding: Also associated with ACOXL at p=1.13×10−11, this SNP complemented findings for rs6731210, suggesting a shared biological locus influencing ERM.
title: Genomewide association study of epiretinal membrane: discovery of significant risk loci in each of three American populations

finding: Linked to significant changes in expression of AC073283.1 in non-macular retinal pigment epithelium with a p-value of 2.86×10−5, indicating its influence on retinal biology.
title: Genomewide association study of epiretinal membrane: discovery of significant risk loci in each of three American populations

finding: SNP rs676210 at the APOB locus was associated with lipid traits and was identified as a protein-altering variant potentially altering the physical properties of apolipoprotein B.
title: Lipoprotein profile and metabolic fine-mapping of genetic lipid risk loci

finding: SNP rs138905573, located upstream of APOB, was associated with varying effects on lipid traits compared to rs676210, indicating different mechanisms of impacting APOB levels.
title: Lipoprotein profile and metabolic fine-mapping of genetic lipid risk loci

finding: SNP rs34011564 was consistently identified as a contributing SNP in all three verifications of super-variant chr2_197. This locus is linked to gene DNAH7, which is significantly downregulated in COVID-19 infected cells and may affect ciliary function.
title: Genetic variants are identified to increase risk of COVID-19 related mortality from UK Biobank data

finding: SNP rs71040457 appeared in all three analyses of the super-variant chr2_197, where it is located near gene SLC39A10, impacting immune cell homeostasis and potentially affecting COVID-19 outcomes.
title: Genetic variants are identified to increase risk of COVID-19 related mortality from UK Biobank data

finding: SNP rs2176724 contributed to super-variant chr2_197's repeated analysis, which ties it back to potential mechanisms influencing COVID-19 severity.
title: Genetic variants are identified to increase risk of COVID-19 related mortality from UK Biobank data

finding: SNP rs4346407 was discussed in relation to super-variant chr2_197 and indicated significant p-values related to gender differences, suggesting a potential connection to heightened risk for male patients.
title: Genetic variants are identified to increase risk of COVID-19 related mortality from UK Biobank data

finding: SNP rs200008298 was part of the super-variant chr2_197 and associated with gene DNAH7, emphasizing its role in respiratory ciliary function, critical for COVID-19 outcomes.
title: Genetic variants are identified to increase risk of COVID-19 related mortality from UK Biobank data

finding: SNP rs183712207 was identified with super-variant chr2_197, linking it significantly to the function of the DNAH7 gene and its impact on COVID-19 mortality.
title: Genetic variants are identified to increase risk of COVID-19 related mortality from UK Biobank data

finding: SNP rs191631470, located in the super-variant chr2_197 alongside DNAH7, highlighted the importance of ciliary movement in determining susceptibility to severe COVID-19.
title: Genetic variants are identified to increase risk of COVID-19 related mortality from UK Biobank data

finding: SNP rs4578880 was included in the identified chr2_197 super-variant, indicating relationships with immune regulation vital for COVID-19 responses.
title: Genetic variants are identified to increase risk of COVID-19 related mortality from UK Biobank data

finding: SNP rs113892140 was linked with super-variant chr2_197, supporting associations with genetic risk factors for COVID-19 mortality.
title: Genetic variants are identified to increase risk of COVID-19 related mortality from UK Biobank data

finding: The study revealed that patients with the IFIH1 rs1990760 TT variant exhibited a significantly lower expression of inflammation-related pathways and an anti-inflammatory cell profile, which correlated with better outcomes in severe COVID-19. Specifically, patients with the TT variant who did not receive steroid treatment all survived their ICU stay, suggesting a protective role against severe forms of the disease. Additionally, the administration of dexamethasone to patients with the TT variant resulted in increased hospital mortality and serum IL-6 levels, indicating that steroids may negate the anti-inflammatory benefits conferred by the TT variant.
title: IFIH1 rs1990760 variants, systemic inflammation and outcome in critically-ill COVID-19 patients

finding: The rs2111485 SNP was found in the IFIH1 locus on chromosome 2, where it indicated local genetic correlation with eosinophil and lymphocyte counts, although the correlation with CAD was not significant.
title: Genetic relations between leukocyte counts, type 1 diabetes, and coronary artery disease

finding: Similar to rs2111485, the rs2075302 SNP was also located within the IFIH1 locus and demonstrated local genetic correlation with eosinophil and lymphocyte counts, reinforcing its potential role in the genetic architecture of these traits and their association with T1D and CAD.
title: Genetic relations between leukocyte counts, type 1 diabetes, and coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs10803744, located within the long noncoding RNA MIR3681HG on chromosome 2, was identified as significant in relation to HCV infection with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.57 and a P-value of 7.99×10^-8 among population-based common controls. In context, allele frequency differed between HCV clearance individuals (MAF=17%) and those with persistent infection (MAF=13%), yet displayed an OR of 1.42 (P=4.06×10^-4). The inconsistency in signal strength across exploratory analyses highlighted the robustness of the association at the MIR3681HG marker.
title: Pathogen exposure misclassification can bias association signals in GWAS of infectious diseases when using population-based common controls

finding: The variant rs1878289 influenced the expression of NGEF in excitatory neurons, with its genetic effect increasing substantially during cellular maturation. This finding contributed to the understanding of dynamic eQTL effects across different stages of neuronal development.
title: Single-Nucleus Atlas of Cell-Type Specific Genetic Regulation in the Human Brain

finding: The lead SNP rs13008848 located at the SLC40A1 locus was associated with spleen iron levels, suggesting a regulatory effect influencing iron transport mediated by ferroportin. Significant co-localization was observed with expression data across various human tissues, reinforcing its role in iron homeostasis.
title: Analysis of MRI-derived spleen iron in the UK Biobank identifies genetic variation linked to iron homeostasis and erythrocyte morphology

finding: This SNP was identified as the causal variant at the 2q37.3 locus associated with IDH-mutant gliomas, particularly linked with eosinophil counts, indicating a shared genetic signal with blood cell traits. The findings suggested that rs34290285 may influence disease susceptibility due to its relationship with eosinophil levels.
title: Genetic predisposition to altered blood cell homeostasis is associated with glioma risk and survival

finding: The SATB2 locus variant rs6435017 was associated with lateralized effects involving lower volume of the posterior insula and left Heschl gyrus, while showing higher volume in the right anterior middle temporal gyrus.
title: Distinct impact modes of polygenic disposition to dyslexia in the adult brain

finding: The SNP rs10191758 was involved in significant colocalization analysis, indicating it shared a causal relationship with PTSD in one of the LE8-related pathways, contributing to shared underlying mechanisms.
title: Genetics of posttraumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular conditions using Life’s Essential 8, Electronic Health Records, and Heart Imaging

finding: The SNP rs197261 was part of the shared loci identified between PTSD and cardiovascular phenotypes, reinforcing its potential as a genetic risk factor.
title: Genetics of posttraumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular conditions using Life’s Essential 8, Electronic Health Records, and Heart Imaging

finding: The study found that the STAT4 SLE risk allele rs7574865[T] was associated with increased IL-12-induced IFN-γ production in T cells from patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This association highlighted the role of genetic variants in modulating immune responses in SLE patients, further linking genetic predisposition to disease mechanisms.
title: The Lupus Epigenome Relates to Genetics, Transcription and Serological Profiles with Dependency on Molecular Subtypes and Informs Drug Discovery

finding: The SNP rs62175241 was identified as a protective allele associated with increased expression of the long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) DIRC3 and its downstream effector IGFBP5. This finding was established through single-cell and bulk eQTL analyses conducted on fibroblasts from healthy donors and tenosynovium samples from CTS patients, indicating that this variant functioned to modulate the expression of critical genes involved in the pathophysiology of both trigger finger (TF) and carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). Additionally, the T allele was linked to attenuation of IGF-1 signaling, providing insights into shared mechanisms for disease susceptibility.
title: DIRC3-IGFBP5 is a shared genetic risk locus and therapeutic target for carpal tunnel syndrome and trigger finger

finding: The index SNP rs10203066 was significantly associated with both trigger finger (TF) and carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) in a genome-wide association study (GWAS). It demonstrated independent associations with TF and CTS with p-values of 6.73×10^-13 and 2.20×10^-12 respectively. This SNP was noted to have a shared signal with previously published CTS GWAS findings, further confirming its role in both diseases and reflecting a strong phenotypic association.
title: DIRC3-IGFBP5 is a shared genetic risk locus and therapeutic target for carpal tunnel syndrome and trigger finger

finding: The variant rs13029479 was associated with obesity and contributed to the leading factor for BMI. It was proximal to the gene TMEM18, and the analysis noted significant enrichment of brain tissue types in the factor characterized by this SNP.
title: A scalable variational approach to characterize pleiotropic components across thousands of human diseases and complex traits using GWAS summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs74676797 was also linked to obesity as part of the genetic basis for BMI, associated with the gene TMEM18. Like rs13029479, this SNP was involved in the leading factor for BMI that showed strong enrichment of brain-specific tissues.
title: A scalable variational approach to characterize pleiotropic components across thousands of human diseases and complex traits using GWAS summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs231779, located near the CTLA4 gene, was associated with autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, hypothyroidism, and type 1 diabetes. Notably, the allele that increased the risk of autoimmune diseases was found to be protective against melanoma and keratinocyte cancers, highlighting a clear pleiotropic effect.
title: Mapping inherited genetic variation with opposite effects on autoimmune disease and cancer identifies candidate drug targets associated with the anti-tumor immune response

finding: Associated with height and located downstream of <italic>IRS1</italic>.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: Identified as a likely false positive for height in UKBB.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: The SNP rs80306347, an intronic variant in the LRP1B gene, was determined to have a strong association with progression to PDD, showing a HR of 3.37 and a p-value of 7.39 x 10^-09. This locus was highlighted as a promising candidate for regulating dementia development in PD.
title: Association between the LRP1B and APOE loci and the development of Parkinson’s disease dementia

finding: The intronic SNP rs116725215 at the LRP1B locus also exhibited a significant association with dementia progression, with a HR of 3.48 and a p-value of 8.49 x 10^-09. This finding indicated that variants in the LRP1B gene play a role in dementia development in PD.
title: Association between the LRP1B and APOE loci and the development of Parkinson’s disease dementia

finding: SNP rs4553827 was linked to systolic and diastolic blood pressure in offspring, with strong associations indicating that it might influence preeclampsia through cardiovascular pathways.
title: Clotting factor genes are associated with preeclampsia in high altitude pregnant women in the Peruvian Andes

finding: The variant rs41416 in the EXOC6B gene was found to be significantly increased among diabetic cases compared to idiopathic cases, with an OR of 3.3 (p-value <10^-7).
title: The role of M1 to M2 macrophage polarization in the etiology of idiopathic gastroparesis: GWAS perspective

finding: The SNP rs62158206 on chromosome 2 was identified as a genome-wide significant locus associated with long sleep duration in European participants, showing an odds ratio of 0.93 and a p-value of 3.6×10^-8. This SNP is intergenic to the PAX8 gene, which is implicated in several sleep-related phenotypes including insomnia.
title: Genome-wide association study investigating short and long sleep duration: a cross-population meta-analysis

finding: This AD GWAS SNP was found in a microglia specific enhancer connected to INPP5D. INPP5D is a phosphatase that plays a role in cell signaling and is associated with Alzheimer's disease, establishing a genetic link via this SNP.
title: Cell-type specific cis-eQTLs in eight brain cell-types identifies novel risk genes for human brain disorders

finding: This SNP, located in a microglia enhancer upstream of BIN1, was predicted to disrupt KLF4 transcription factor binding, implicating it in Alzheimer's disease by affecting microglial function.
title: Cell-type specific cis-eQTLs in eight brain cell-types identifies novel risk genes for human brain disorders

finding: The rs744373 SNP was associated with increased tau-PET levels, indicating that individuals with this genetic variant displayed higher levels of tau pathology, which is relevant for understanding cognitive decline and memory impairment in Alzheimer's disease.
title: Tau-PET and in vivo Braak-staging as a prognostic marker in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs6733839 was part of a previously fine-mapped locus in European populations with a posterior probability (PP) greater than 0.8, indicating strong evidence of its role in Alzheimer's disease risk.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis and fine-mapping in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs10933431 was also part of a previously identified AD locus confirmed in European populations, indicating its significance to AD.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis and fine-mapping in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: was designated an intergenic variant between FAP and IFIH1, where it indicated potential immunological roles affecting cancer progression.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: involved in glucose metabolism, highlighting its association with cardiometabolic effects on BCC/SCC risk.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: The well-known variant rs1427407 at the BCL11A locus was shown to overlap with accessible chromatin and was one of the variants that contributed to HbF regulation. It was significant in various ancestry groups, illustrating the complex independent signals present at this locus.
title: Genetic regulation of fetal hemoglobin across global populations

finding: Colocalized with eQTLs, this variant presented connections with HIBCH protein associated with various blood traits.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: Determined to be associated with the TP53I3 protein, highlighting its role in mediating genetic influences on proteome expression.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: This SNP was identified in association with RA and COVID-19 hospitalization, contributing to the shared genetic architecture.
title: Disentangling the common genetic architecture and causality of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus with COVID-19 outcomes: genome-wide cross trait analysis and bi-directional Mendelian randomization study

finding: The SNP rs1047891, located in the CPS1 gene, was significantly associated with serum glycine levels (P=7.8E-1101) and linked to decreased risk of coronary artery disease (CAD), although not at genome-wide significance. This association was noted to exhibit a female-specific pattern, highlighting potential sexually dimorphic effects in cardiometabolic traits.
title: Effect of Genetic and Dietary Perturbation of Glycine Metabolism on Atherosclerosis in Humans and Mice

finding: The synonymous SNV on RAB10 (rs149622307) was significantly replicated in the Cox regression analysis, indicating a robust association with AD risk.
title: A novel age-informed approach for genetic association analysis in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The rs2708954 SNP was identified to affect IL37 expression, with a main effect beta of -0.77 and significant interaction beta of -0.79 in inflamed skin (FDR = 7.73e-7). IL37 is known for its anti-inflammatory role, which suggests its regulatory importance in psoriasis.
title: Immunosuppression causes dynamic changes in expression QTLs in psoriatic skin

finding: The study found that rs1067327, located within a chromosomal region associated with three genes (CAMKMT, PREPL, SLC3A1), had a robust negative correlation with drinking behaviors in individuals treated with OSU6162. Specifically, higher anxiety factor score polygenic risk scores (PRSs) associated with lower number of drinks consumed, percentage of heavy drinking days, and changes in blood phosphatidylethanol (PEth) levels (FDR<0.05). This association was absent in the placebo group, indicating a potential predictive value of anxiety PRS for treatment response to OSU6162 in alcohol dependence patients.
title: Genetic liability for anxiety associates with treatment response to the monoamine stabilizer OSU6162 in alcohol dependence

finding: The SNP rs1427407 was associated with increased production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and demonstrated a significant effect on HbF titres, accounting for 20% of variation in HbF levels. Additionally, this SNP contributed to protection from clinical malaria but was linked to increased gametocyte prevalence, thus enhancing parasite transmissibility.
title: Fetal hemoglobin enables malaria parasite growth in sickle cells but augments production of transmission stage parasites

finding: The variant rs838717, an intronic variant in DGKD, was associated with a 4.30 odds ratio for increased kidney stone disease risk due to a 1 standard deviation increase in serum calcium. This finding related to the impaired transduction of calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) signaling.
title: Genetic variants predisposing to increased risk of kidney stone disease

finding: The locus rs7564805 in SAG showed a significant association (P = 6.16 x 10<sup>-29</sup>) with PRC layer thickness and is associated with Oguchi disease, which affects night vision.
title: Sub-cellular level resolution of common genetic variation in the photoreceptor layer identifies continuum between rare disease and common variation

finding: The SNP rs869016 in MERTK demonstrated differential effects across concentric fields of the OS and has associations with retinal dystrophies including retinitis pigmentosa.
title: Sub-cellular level resolution of common genetic variation in the photoreceptor layer identifies continuum between rare disease and common variation

finding: The SNP rs201030469 in TNS1 had an impact on PRC layer thickness and was also associated with breast cancer diagnosis, indicating complex interrelations between traits.
title: Sub-cellular level resolution of common genetic variation in the photoreceptor layer identifies continuum between rare disease and common variation

finding: The SNP rs17183814 was identified as a missense variant in the gene SCN2A, which was previously recognized for its association with seizures and developmental and epileptic encephalopathy. This finding highlighted the potential role of SCN2A in the etiology of bipolar disorder (BD).
title: Fine-mapping genomic loci refines bipolar disorder risk genes

finding: The study identified rs2542580, a cis-pQTL for the protein ERLEC1, which was linked to an increased risk of human haemorrhoidal disease (HEM) with a highly significant p-value of 5.18e-07. The high expression levels of ERLEC1 were supported by differential expression analysis in haemorrhoidal tissues compared to normal specimens. Furthermore, strong colocalization evidence (H4>0.9) was found between ERLEC1 and HEM, corroborated by findings in the INTERVAL cohort.
title: Research Letter: Therapeutic targets for haemorrhoidal disease: proteome-wide Mendelian randomisation and colocalization analyses

finding: The SNP rs3732218 was linked to the UGT1A* locus and was associated with clozapine and norclozapine plasma concentrations. Its role reinforced previous suggestions of causal variants affecting pharmacokinetics, indicating its importance in understanding clozapine metabolism across various ancestries.
title: Pharmacokinetics and pharmacogenomics of clozapine in an ancestrally diverse sample: A longitudinal analysis and GWAS using clinical monitoring data from the UK

finding: This SNP was noted to be significant as a cis-eQTL for IL18R1 in Th17 memory cells, which plays a role in inflammatory responses.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: The SNP rs1260326, identified as a missense variant at the GCKR locus, displayed associations with 11 traits. This specific variant provided insights into genetic influences on various phenotypes.
title: Genome-wide study on 72,298 Korean individuals in Korean biobank data for 76 traits identifies hundreds of novel loci

finding: The rs744373 SNP in the BIN1 gene was found to be associated with increased tau-PET levels and impaired memory in Alzheimer's disease. This association was part of a broader study investigating genetic risk factors for AD and highlighted the significance of this SNP in the context of tau pathology and cognitive impairment.
title: Cell-type-specific Alzheimer’s disease polygenic risk scores are associated with distinct disease processes in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs60473748, located within the AFF3 locus, was found to have a highly significant association with educational attainment, specifically linked with obtaining a university degree. The peak association was noted with a p-value of 7.9x10^-11, indicating a strong correlation. This finding was particularly relevant as it underscored the independent effect of the GCC tandem repeat expansion in AFF3 on educational outcomes, even after controlling for the presence of this lead SNP.
title: A phenome-wide association study of methylated GC-rich repeats identifies a GCC repeat expansion in AFF3 as a significant cause of intellectual disability

finding: This variant was identified on chromosome 2 and associated with the AA %LAA950 NetSHy2 score. It was previously linked to smoking intensity and functioned as an eQTL for MGAT5, a gene involved in glycosylation implicated in cancer and COPD pathogenesis, revealing its role in network regulation.
title: Proteomic Networks and Related Genetic Variants Associated with Smoking and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

finding: This SNP was associated with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) in a large meta-analysis involving 7,747 PCOS cases and 498,227 controls. It was identified as a novel locus on chromosome 2 within the gene MSH6, which is involved in DNA repair. The SNP served as an expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) in multiple relevant tissues, including the thyroid and ovaries. It also has relevance in menopause age and ovarian aging.
title: Understanding and Predicting Polycystic Ovary Syndrome through Shared Genetic Architecture with Testosterone, SHBG, and Inflammatory Markers

finding: The SNP rs1606803 at locus 2p11.2 was associated with brain stem volume and ease of getting up, highlighting its connection to sleep traits.
title: The role of sleep in the human brain and body: insights from multi-organ imaging genetics

finding: The variant rs62158206 in locus 2q14.1 was connected with sleep duration and resting functional connectivity, shedding light on sleep's genetic influences.
title: The role of sleep in the human brain and body: insights from multi-organ imaging genetics

finding: Ranked highest for gene prioritization at its locus with a score of 1384 for IL18R1, demonstrating significant expression colocalization in various immune cells and the skin of AD patients.
title: Triangulating molecular evidence to prioritise candidate causal genes at established atopic dermatitis loci

finding: Alongside rs6419573, this SNP was also a lead signal for IL18RAP, both contributing significantly to AD risk through substantial expression evidence.
title: Triangulating molecular evidence to prioritise candidate causal genes at established atopic dermatitis loci

finding: The rs62158170 variant at 2q14.1 showed a colocalization with insomnia, affecting the functional connectivity between auditory and posterior multimodal networks, primarily observed in resting fMRI.
title: Genetic influences on the intrinsic and extrinsic functional organizations of the cerebral cortex

finding: The variant rs56093896 in 2q14.1 was linked to insomnia, showing its influence on the functional connectivity between auditory and posterior multimodal networks within the resting fMRI context.
title: Genetic influences on the intrinsic and extrinsic functional organizations of the cerebral cortex

finding: The SNP rs17757829 was identified as a significant risk locus in the male-only analysis, which was not significant in the main analysis, highlighting distinct genetic variations contributing to BPD.
title: Genome-wide association study of borderline personality disorder identifies six loci and highlights shared risk with mental and somatic disorders

finding: The rs6733839 variant in the BIN1 gene showed a significant association with delirium (Odds Ratio of 1.015, p = 7×10^-25), reinforcing its implication in Alzheimer's disease pathophysiology and possibly delirium.
title: Dissecting the genetic and proteomic risk factors for delirium

finding: The SNP rs1047891 in the CPS1 gene at locus 2q34 emerged as a significant protective factor against MacTel, with the minor 'A' allele being associated with reduced disease risk. This allele resulted in a T1406N substitution that decreased the enzyme's binding affinity, potentially affecting glycine metabolism and thereby influencing MacTel pathology.
title: Identification of genetic factors influencing metabolic dysregulation and retinal support for MacTel, a retinal disorder

finding: The SNP rs2160387 was identified at locus 2p14 within the SLC1A4 gene and reached GW-significance in the study (P=5.9×10-09), highlighting its role in MacTel pathogenesis.
title: Identification of genetic factors influencing metabolic dysregulation and retinal support for MacTel, a retinal disorder

finding: The rs4663105 variant at the BIN1 locus demonstrated significant associations with both AD+LB- (OR = 1.40, p = 6.5 × 10^-10) and AD+LB+ (OR = 1.53, p = 1.4 × 10^-10) when compared to no pathology. There was no significant association with LB+ compared to no pathology (OR = 1.10, p = 0.48) or AD+LB+ versus AD+LB- (OR = 1.13, p = 0.019). Thus, like APOE-ε4, rs4663105 was found to be a risk factor for AD pathology, not for the sole risk of LB pathology.
title: APOE-ε4 and BIN1 increase risk of Alzheimer’s disease pathology but not specifically of Lewy body pathology

finding: The rs1260326 variant in the GCKR gene was notably pleiotropic, associated with multiple metabolites including plasma pyruvate, which illustrated the complex regulation of metabolite levels.
title: Mendelian randomisation with proxy exposures: challenges and opportunities

finding: The SNP rs6544366 in the APOB locus demonstrated a significant association in the stringent filtering scenarios for TC response to statins with a beta of -0.069 (p-value = 3.22e-9), reaffirming its genetic involvement in cholesterol metabolism.
title: Leveraging large-scale biobank EHRs to enhance pharmacogenetics of cardiometabolic disease medications

finding: Variant rs11893824, associated with the LIMS2 gene (LIM Zinc Finger Domain Containing 2), emerged as another novel variant linked to sVEGFR2 levels. The analysis showed that elevated sVEGFR2 levels predicted by this variant were similarly associated with a decreased risk of MP, with an odds ratio reported at 0.86.
title: Genetic Evidence for Soluble VEGFR2 as a Protective Factor Against Macular Pucker

finding: Located 2KB upstream of VAMP5 and serving as a cis-miR-eQTL for miR-6701, rs1254901 was linked to ischemic heart disease-related conditions, illustrating its clinical relevance.
title: An atlas of genetic regulation and disease associations of microRNAs

finding: The SNP rs3749034, found within the promoter region of GAD1, was associated with the expression of long and short isoforms of GAD1 in the hippocampus. This correlation connected the variant to risk factors for both schizophrenia (SZ) and autism spectrum disorder (ASD), demonstrating its impact on gene isoform expression.
title: Long-read sequencing reveals the RNA isoform repertoire of neuropsychiatric risk genes in human brain

finding: The SNP rs16840252 was part of the meQTL linked to CTLA4 and found only in naive CD4+ T cells of lupus patients, underscoring its relevance in modulating T cell function in the context of lupus.
title: Hypomethylation of miR-17-92 cluster in lupus T cells and no significant role for genetic factors in the lupus-associated DNA methylation signature

finding: The SNP rs4553808 was associated with the meQTL for CTLA4 as well, appearing in naive CD4+ T cells from lupus patients, reinforcing its potential impact on CD4+ T cell activation and response.
title: Hypomethylation of miR-17-92 cluster in lupus T cells and no significant role for genetic factors in the lupus-associated DNA methylation signature

finding: The lead SNP rs17362588, located within the CCDC141 gene, was associated with pulse rate and maximum heart rate. This variant has previously been linked to several cardiovascular traits, showing its relevance in cardiac physiology.
title: Distinct Genetic Loci and Variations in Blood Pressure and Pulse Rate in Europeans and Africans from the UK Biobank

finding: This variant, located in intron 2 of ZNF804A, was novel and associated with AUD. It was relevant as it was linked to a previously reported increased susceptibility to psychosis traits including schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, as well as heroin addiction.
title: Genetic underpinnings of the transition from alcohol consumption to alcohol use disorder: shared and unique genetic architectures in a cross-ancestry sample

finding: A novel variant near COBLL1 associated with AUDIT-C, this SNP was polymorphic across populations and had associations with other traits such as Type 2 diabetes.
title: Genetic underpinnings of the transition from alcohol consumption to alcohol use disorder: shared and unique genetic architectures in a cross-ancestry sample

finding: Located in GCKR, this variant indicated equal direct and indirect effects on AUD, contributing insights into the metabolic influences of alcohol.
title: Genetic underpinnings of the transition from alcohol consumption to alcohol use disorder: shared and unique genetic architectures in a cross-ancestry sample

finding: SNP rs74265878 was identified within the novel categories of the AFR population with notable associations to cardiovascular traits, making it a positive and original finding.
title: Multitrait Genome-Wide Analysis in the UK Biobank Reveals Novel and Distinct Variants Influencing Cardiovascular Traits in Africans and Europeans

finding: The SNP rs887829 at the UGT1A locus on 2q37.1 was significant with a p-value of 2.2 × 10-8 in European ancestry individuals, suggesting its involvement in glycemic traits.
title: Characterizing common and rare variations in non-traditional glycemic biomarkers using multivariate approaches on multi-ancestry ARIC study

finding: The rs114780578 variant in the ABCG5 gene showed an odds ratio of 1.44 within the splice region, suggesting an increased risk of hyperlipidaemia, although it was considered not statistically significant overall in the context of LOF variants.
title: Weighted burden analysis of rare coding variants in 470,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank subject characterises effects on hyperlipidaemia risk

finding: Variant rs370895243 in the ABCG5 splice region was part of a larger signal indicating increased hyperlipidaemia risk with an OR of 1.44, suggesting its contribution to variations in lipid profiles among individuals.
title: Weighted burden analysis of rare coding variants in 470,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank subject characterises effects on hyperlipidaemia risk

finding: The rs201469377 variant in ABCG5 was also contributing to the increase in hyperlipidaemia risk, as indicated by its presence in the splice region category that showed higher associations with cases compared to controls.
title: Weighted burden analysis of rare coding variants in 470,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank subject characterises effects on hyperlipidaemia risk

finding: The variant rs140374206 in ABCG5 had a frequency suggesting a slight increase in hyperlipidaemia risk, despite not being strongly significant, indicating the importance of normal variants in lipid metabolism.
title: Weighted burden analysis of rare coding variants in 470,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank subject characterises effects on hyperlipidaemia risk

finding: The rs5742904 variant (c.10580G>A, p.Arg3527Gln) located in the APOB gene was found to be a founder pathogenic mutation for familial hypercholesterolemia. Its significantly higher allele frequency was documented in the Old Order Amish population, thereby explaining the increased risk for coronary artery atherosclerosis in this demographic.
title: Decoding Genetics, Ancestry, and Geospatial Context for Precision Health

finding: At the TMEM18 locus, rs7579427 was identified as a lead variant with significant associations with childhood obesity. It was shown to contact the promoters of multiple genes across various cell types.
title: 3D genomic features across >50 diverse cell types reveal insights into the genomic architecture of childhood obesity

finding: Similar to rs7579427, rs62104180 was one of the lead independent variants at the TMEM18 locus and was linked to the expression of multiple effector genes specifically across various immune and metabolic cell types.
title: 3D genomic features across >50 diverse cell types reveal insights into the genomic architecture of childhood obesity

finding: The lead variant rs4077678 at the ADCY3 locus implicating this gene as a significant effector gene in 29 different cell types including metabolic and immune cells was noted, revealing its relevance to pediatric obesity.
title: 3D genomic features across >50 diverse cell types reveal insights into the genomic architecture of childhood obesity

finding: At the TMEM18 locus, rs35796073 consistently contacted the ALKAL2 promoter across multiple cell types, suggesting an important relationship influencing obesity susceptibility.
title: 3D genomic features across >50 diverse cell types reveal insights into the genomic architecture of childhood obesity

finding: This SNP also showed a strong association at the TMEM18 locus, contacting the promoters of genes like ALKAL2 and being involved in colocalization analyses in various cell types relevant to obesity.
title: 3D genomic features across >50 diverse cell types reveal insights into the genomic architecture of childhood obesity

finding: This SNP was significantly observed at the TMEM18 locus, reinforcing its role in gene regulation related to childhood obesity susceptibility.
title: 3D genomic features across >50 diverse cell types reveal insights into the genomic architecture of childhood obesity

finding: SNP rs73978419, located near GRB14, showed a significant association in the Hispanic population, with a P-value of 1.3×10^-8 and an odds ratio of 0.44, suggesting it may reduce the risk for AD.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide meta-analysis of 56,241 individuals identifies LRRC4C, LHX5-AS1 and nominates ancestry-specific loci PTPRK, GRB14, and KIAA0825 as novel risk loci for Alzheimer’s disease: the Alzheimer’s Disease Genetics Consortium

finding: The SNP rs34532804 related to the GREB1 locus at 2p25.1 showed a significant association (P = 6.55x10-4), indicating its potential impact on endometriosis.
title: Enhancing Genetic Association Power in Endometriosis through Unsupervised Clustering of Clinical Subtypes Identified from Electronic Health Records

finding: The SNP rs955658 was found to have a CADD score above 12.37, indicating potential deleteriousness. It was part of the 40 PTSD risk loci discovered, associated with GSA traits, and displayed opposite effects in PTSD compared to GSA.
title: The genetic relationships between post-traumatic stress disorder and its corresponding neural circuit structures

finding: SNP rs668948 demonstrated a positive original finding, where it colocalized with cg05337441 (APOB), an LDL-associated CpG, related to coronary artery disease at a PPFC of 0.8. This SNP explained 41% of the observed colocalization, indicating its significant role in LDL metabolism and cardiovascular disease.
title: Elucidating the genetic architecture of DNA methylation to identify promising molecular mechanisms of disease

finding: The SNP rs7605824, located on chromosome 2, was associated with accelerated eye fundus aging, displaying a strong signal with a minimum p-value of 2.4×10^-180. It was found in close proximity to the <FAM150B> gene (also known as <ALKAL2>, an ALK ligand), suggesting a significant genetic factor linked to the aging of the eye fundus.
title: Deep learning of fundus and optical coherence tomography images enables identification of diverse genetic and environmental factors associated with eye aging

finding: The SNP rs55742348 was associated with OCT-measured eye aging, with a notable p-value of 3×10^-13. This SNP was located near the <SH3YL1> gene, indicating its potential relevance in the genetic component of eye aging as assessed by optical coherence tomography.
title: Deep learning of fundus and optical coherence tomography images enables identification of diverse genetic and environmental factors associated with eye aging

finding: The SNP rs1800440 was identified as one of the lead SNPs linked to GrimAge DNAm pack years. It was previously documented in the GWAS Catalog and associated with carcinogenesis, which relates to the biological effects of smoking.
title: Blood- and brain-based genome-wide association studies of smoking

finding: The SNP rs114342890, which was not previously annotated in the GWAS Catalog, mapped to RMDN2:RMDN2-AS1, a long non-coding RNA studied regarding eosinophil counts and melanoma. Its association was of interest due to its potential regulatory mechanisms related to smoking.
title: Blood- and brain-based genome-wide association studies of smoking

finding: The SNP rs142556838, an intron variant near the CCDC141 locus, was associated with several cardiometabolic traits, including diastolic blood pressure. It also participated in cardiomyocyte regulation, evident from its association with a DNAse hypersensitivity peak in the cardiac tissue.
title: Unsupervised cardiac MRI phenotyping with 3D diffusion autoencoders reveals novel genetic insights

finding: The SNP rs6544713 located in ABCG8 was identified through the combined approach for coronary atherosclerosis and was previously associated with the risk of coronary artery disease in literature.
title: Genetic association studies using disease liabilities from deep neural networks

finding: The p.F4C variant in AP1S3, related to Psoriasis 15 (OMIM: 616106), was annotated as likely pathogenic and functionally validated in HEK293 and HaCaT cells, showing decreased activity of the mutant protein.
title: Genetic landscape of rare autoinflammatory disease variants in Qatar and Middle Eastern populations through the integration of whole-genome and exome datasets

finding: The <italic>ODC1</italic> variant rs2302615 was positively associated with gastric cancer in a case-control study involving 664 gastric cancer cases and 702 controls. The odds ratio (OR) was 1.36 (p = 0.018), indicating an increased risk for individuals with this SNP, particularly strong in those homozygous for the risk allele C.
title: Ornithine Decarboxylase (ODC1) gene variant (rs2302615) is associated with gastric cancer independently of Helicobacter pylori CagA serostatus

finding: The <italic>CYP1B1</italic> SNP rs1056836 was associated with gastric cancer, showing an odds ratio of 0.77 (p = 0.008) in the high-risk population, suggesting a protective effect.
title: Ornithine Decarboxylase (ODC1) gene variant (rs2302615) is associated with gastric cancer independently of Helicobacter pylori CagA serostatus

finding: Similar to rs1056836, the <italic>CYP1B1</italic> SNP rs1800440 also showed a significant association with gastric cancer (p = 0.011), reinforcing the relevance of CYP1B1 variants in cancer risk.
title: Ornithine Decarboxylase (ODC1) gene variant (rs2302615) is associated with gastric cancer independently of Helicobacter pylori CagA serostatus

finding: The SNP rs1402906 was found to be significantly associated with cognitive preservation in an Amish population. It demonstrated a high linkage and association with cognitive function, specifically impacting the expression of the gene CTNNA2 and influencing the binding of transcription factors such as POU3F2 and POU1F1a. Individuals with the T allele of rs1402906 were more likely to belong to the cognitively unimpaired group. The association highlighted that this locus played a role in modulating gene expression related to neurocognition.
title: Genetic analysis of cognitive preservation in the midwestern Amish reveals a novel locus on chromosome 2

finding: The SNP rs62183854 was identified within a distal intergenic OCR, which exhibited significant co-accessibility with promoter OCRs for the genes DLX1 and DLX2. These genes are transcription factors crucial for GABAergic neuron development, contributing to the genetic architecture of schizophrenia through their regulatory influence.
title: Genetic implication of prenatal GABAergic and cholinergic neuron development in susceptibility to schizophrenia

finding: The rs1662979 SNP was shown to increase the risk of critically ill COVID-19 due to its influence in promoting higher nephronectin (NPNT) levels, which were associated with increased odds of severe COVID-19. Interestingly, this SNP also correlated with improved lung function metrics (higher FEV1/FVC ratio) and reduced risk of COPD, suggesting distinct mechanisms at play in the severity risk of COVID-19.
title: Proteome-wide Mendelian randomization implicates nephronectin as an actionable mediator of the effect of obesity on COVID-19 severity

finding: This SNP was linked to female infertility with a strong association (P=4×10^-9), underscoring its importance in reproductive genetics.
title: Leveraging large-scale multi-omics to identify therapeutic targets from genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs62148876 was associated with SCQ stereotyped at a p-value of 4 × 10^-7, and it is located within an intron of the LTBP1 gene, which has associations with depression and Alzheimer's disease.
title: Clinical autism subscales have common genetic liability that is heritable, pleiotropic, and generalizable to the general population

finding: The SNP rs62134085 was identified with a significant association with smoking initiation (p=1×10−18). This finding was part of a broader investigation that linked genetic regions to behaviors related to tobacco smoking.
title: Brain-wide pleiotropy investigation of alcohol drinking and tobacco smoking behaviors

finding: The SNP rs305191 was significantly associated with educational attainment (p=2×10−14). This association highlighted the potential influence of genetics on cognitive-related traits within the context of tobacco smoking.
title: Brain-wide pleiotropy investigation of alcohol drinking and tobacco smoking behaviors

finding: The SNP rs848552 showed a significant correlation with chronotype (p=5×10−14). This finding suggested possible genetic links between time-related behavioral traits and tobacco smoking initiation.
title: Brain-wide pleiotropy investigation of alcohol drinking and tobacco smoking behaviors

finding: The SNP rs6708545 demonstrated a significant association with self-reported math ability (p=1×10−10). This association pointed towards genetic influences that might intertwine cognitive abilities and smoking behaviors.
title: Brain-wide pleiotropy investigation of alcohol drinking and tobacco smoking behaviors

finding: The SNP rs6728742 was linked to cognitive performance (p=1×10−8). This finding added to the understanding of genetic factors that contribute to cognitive function in relation to smoking behaviors.
title: Brain-wide pleiotropy investigation of alcohol drinking and tobacco smoking behaviors

finding: The SNP rs1017154 was significantly associated with cortical thickness (p=3×10−8). This finding emphasized the role of genetic variation in brain structure and its potential relationship to tobacco smoking habits.
title: Brain-wide pleiotropy investigation of alcohol drinking and tobacco smoking behaviors

finding: The T allele of rs1530578 was linked to elevated TMB in ovarian cancer and reduced expression of the GLI2 gene across tissues.
title: Germline cancer gene expression quantitative trait loci influence local and global tumor mutations

finding: The SNP rs72813410 was associated with female PTS factor 1 (PTS-f1) as well, and it was positionally mapped to an intronic region of the WDPCP gene. It showed a beta value of -0.08 and a p-value of 1.94×10^-8, demonstrating its significance. This SNP had previously been detected in studies regarding smoking initiation and the age of first sexual intercourse, indicating its relevance to behavioral traits and potentially to emotional responses related to PTSD.
title: Sex-stratified genomic structural equation models of posttraumatic stress inform PTSD etiology

finding: The SNP rs1549339 was associated with mRNA expression variations in the PSMD1 gene among workers exposed to arsenic. This finding was significant within the context of health impacts related to environmental exposure, indicating potential implications for respiratory health.
title: Brick kiln pollution and its impact on health: A systematic review and meta-analysis

finding: The SNP rs13402242 was also linked to mRNA expression variations in the PSMD1 gene among arsenic-exposed workers. This highlighted a genetic factor that may influence health outcomes related to high pollution exposure, particularly respiratory issues in the context of occupational hazards.
title: Brick kiln pollution and its impact on health: A systematic review and meta-analysis

finding: This variant was identified as an sQTL for SCN2A, noted for splicing dysregulation in bipolar disorder, and has been associated with rare variants in autism spectrum disorder and epilepsy.
title: Cross-ancestry, cell-type-informed atlas of gene, isoform, and splicing regulation in the developing human brain

finding: The rare variant rs138707495 in the 3' UTR of GDF7 was associated with increased risk of head and neck cancer, with an odds ratio of 3.06 (95% CI: 2.07, 4.53, p_meta=2.33×10^-8).
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The SNP rs12616502 showed association with pernicious anemia and was linked to the PNPT1 and CCDC104 genes. This region had established connections with autoimmune conditions such as vitiligo and hypothyroidism.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies five risk loci for pernicious anemia and implicates the role of HLA-DR15 haplotype

finding: The SNP rs1014444 was positively associated with cheese consumption (p=2.04×10⁻⁸) and cognitive performance (p=1.26×10⁻⁹). Additionally, it had positive associations with intelligence (p=5.45×10⁻¹²), years of schooling (p=1.80×10⁻¹²), and resting-state functional MRI connectivity (p=1.48×10⁻¹¹). This finding highlighted the potential role of cheese consumption in enhancing cognitive functions.
title: Integration of Mendelian Randomization and Genome-wide Association Analysis Reveals Potential Benefits of Cheese Intake on Human Intelligence

finding: The SNP rs1260326 was strongly associated with higher PXS-T2D scores, with a beta of 0.01. This missense variant located in the GCKR gene, expressed in liver and beta cells, had previous associations with type 2 diabetes (OR = 1.1). It was aligned with risk factors like total cholesterol and fasting glucose, indicating a complex interaction with metabolic traits.
title: Assessing the genetic contribution of cumulative behavioral factors associated with longitudinal type 2 diabetes risk highlights adiposity and the brain-metabolic axis

finding: TMEM163 rs6430538 was influential in the prediction of clinical features of PD and was part of multi-SNP configurations affecting alpha-synuclein levels.
title: The multi-modality neuroimaging analysis identified an essential genetic variant associated with Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs114656810 was shown to interact with the pathogenic rs429358 SNP and demonstrated a restricted but significant association with AD, suggesting a modifying effect on the pathogenic risk linked to APOE.
title: Novel Alzheimer’s disease genes and epistasis identified using machine learning GWAS platform

finding: This was noted as a novel locus associated with retinal thickness, confirming its significance in the context of retinal health.
title: Multi-omic spatial effects on high-resolution AI-derived retinal thickness

finding: The rs180177180 (G>A) allele frequency was significantly higher in the patient population (29.2%) compared to controls (5.9%). This finding indicated an increased risk of nephrolithiasis in individuals with the A allele, confirming its relevance in genetic susceptibility to kidney stone disease in this cohort.
title: Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) identifies Homozygous mutation in g.37429732G>A in GRHPR gene is responsible for early onset of nephrolithiasis in the population of West Bengal, India

finding: The SNP rs1260326 was highlighted as the likely causal variant for the gene GCKR on chromosome 2, affecting retinol levels through its metabolic role, showcasing a clear genetic influence on retinol regulation.
title: Genetic influences on circulating retinol and its relationship to human health

finding: SNP rs6432708 was identified as an intronic variant in DPP4, which was associated with all four substance use traits.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: SNP rs1260326 was an exonic variant in GCKR confirmed to be GWS in AUD GWAS.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: SNP rs1366839, an intronic variant in ZNF804A, was novel and associated with AUD.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: SNP rs4675308 was identified near WDR12 as a novel intergenic variant associated with smoking.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: The variant rs4988235 located in the MCM6 gene was associated specifically with pentadecanoic acid, showcasing a distinct genetic effect despite the high correlation with myristic acid.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals shared and distinct genetic architecture underlying fatty acid and bioactive oxylipin metabolites in the Hispanic Community Health Study/Study of Latinos (HCHS/SOL)

finding: The missense variant rs9288513 in the PECR gene was uniquely associated with a putative novel oxylipin that exhibited the highest heritability among all oxylipins studied.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals shared and distinct genetic architecture underlying fatty acid and bioactive oxylipin metabolites in the Hispanic Community Health Study/Study of Latinos (HCHS/SOL)

finding: The SNP rs11677238 was nominally significant for the SSRI/SNRI non-response meta-analysis, indicating association with a sample that included 135,471 individuals. The nearest gene was RABL2A, suggesting a potential link to treatment response.
title: Genome-wide meta-analyses of non-response to antidepressants identify novel loci and potential drugs

finding: The nearby SNP rs10195252 in GRB14 was found to be associated at genome-wide levels of significance with waist-to-hip ratio (WHR), triglycerides (TGs), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C). Its associations extend to total cholesterol and type 2 diabetes (T2D), indicating a broad relevance to cardiometabolic traits.
title: Identification of Genetic Loci Simultaneously Associated with Multiple Cardiometabolic Traits

finding: This SNP was notably associated with IgAN under the recessive model, with a P_BONF value of 1.545 × 10^-9, indicating its potential role in the disease pathogenesis.
title: Candidate genes for IgA nephropathy in pediatric patients: exome-wide association study

finding: The SNP rs113851554, located within the MEIS1 gene, was identified as the top variant associated with sleep problems as well as in previous GWAS of insomnia and restless leg syndrome.
title: Investigating the genetic relationship between depression symptoms and Alzheimer’s Disease in clinically diagnosed and proxy cases

finding: In the genetic analyses, rs115843863 was associated with clozapine-induced HDL changes and achieved genome-wide significance (p = 2.05e-08, FDR = 0.0287). This SNP was found near the UPP2 gene, which is involved in uridine metabolism.
title: Pharmacogenetic Study of Antipsychotic-Induced Lipid and BMI Changes in Chinese Schizophrenia Patients: A Genome-Wide Association Study

finding: Similar to the other SNPs, rs2011425 was part of the four index SNPs previously identified in relation to clozapine. Its analysis aimed to clarify the pharmacokinetic profile of clozapine therapy, contributing to a better understanding of dosage personalization.
title: Rare Variants in Pharmacogenes Influence Clozapine Metabolism in Individuals with Schizophrenia

finding: This missense variant in LY75 was also associated with a reduced risk of DNMT3A-CHIP, showing an odds ratio of 0.78, indicating strong protective effects.
title: Exome sequencing of 628,388 individuals identifies common and rare variant associations with clonal hematopoiesis phenotypes

finding: There was a significant association found between SNP rs13020252 and the expression of the novel immunomarker Wilms' Tumor 1 (WT1) in dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP). The study indicated that high expression levels of WT1 were correlated with this specific SNP, suggesting its potential utility as a diagnostic marker in distinguishing DFSP from other similar lesions. This finding was based on an immunohistochemical analysis that included a series of 114 cases.
title: Immunohistochemical profiles of dermatofibroma and dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans: A scoping review

finding: The lead SNP rs115697725[G] in KLHL29 co-localized with traits for mean corpuscular volume and hemoglobin parameters. It had a beta of 0.06 and a p-value of 4.8e-8, with posterior probability indicating a strong connection with iron-related traits.
title: Analysis of MRI-derived spleen iron in the UK Biobank identifies genetic variation linked to iron recycling and erythrocyte morphology

finding: Similar to rs1358596, this SNP exhibited a significant degree of linkage disequilibrium within its credible set, suggesting a role in DMD pathophysiology.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of loss of ambulation in dystrophinopathy patients suggests multiple candidate modifiers of disease severity

finding: At the G6PC2 locus, rs2232326 was identified as a significant rare variant associated with fasting glucose (FG). It showed a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.01 and was found to be disruptive and likely damaging, with weak transcription in islets. It contributed significantly to the association alongside other common variants in haplotype analyses.
title: Whole Genome Sequence Association Analysis of Fasting Glucose and Fasting Insulin Levels in Diverse Cohorts from the NHLBI TOPMed Program

finding: Also at the G6PC2 locus, rs560887 was noted as a common variant in previous GWAS. It served as the primary signal indicating a glucose-raising effect. Its contribution to the glucose-lowering haplotypes was illustrated, reaffirming previous associations.
title: Whole Genome Sequence Association Analysis of Fasting Glucose and Fasting Insulin Levels in Diverse Cohorts from the NHLBI TOPMed Program

finding: At the G6PC2 locus, this variant was identified as a secondary signal in FG association analyses. It was moderately linked to rs492594 and was involved in haplotype contributions to glucose-lowering effects.
title: Whole Genome Sequence Association Analysis of Fasting Glucose and Fasting Insulin Levels in Diverse Cohorts from the NHLBI TOPMed Program

finding: This variant at the G6PC2 locus, identified during the analysis, was rare, with a MAF of 0.01. It contributed significantly to FG associations, particularly in haplotype contexts, indicating a glucose-lowering effect.
title: Whole Genome Sequence Association Analysis of Fasting Glucose and Fasting Insulin Levels in Diverse Cohorts from the NHLBI TOPMed Program

finding: Identified at the G6PC2 locus, this rare variant was included in haplotypes that demonstrated glucose-lowering effects. Its contributions were consistent with previously reported associations.
title: Whole Genome Sequence Association Analysis of Fasting Glucose and Fasting Insulin Levels in Diverse Cohorts from the NHLBI TOPMed Program

finding: Also at the G6PC2 locus, this common variant showed a consistent association with FG. It was part of haplotypes indicating glucose-lowering effects and had previous linkage to T2D risks.
title: Whole Genome Sequence Association Analysis of Fasting Glucose and Fasting Insulin Levels in Diverse Cohorts from the NHLBI TOPMed Program

finding: The SNP rs2741047 in the UGT1A8 locus interacted with sex factors contributing to bilirubin levels, showing that it was a noteworthy vQTL finding.
title: Hypothesis-free detection of gene-interaction effects on biomarker concentration in UK Biobank using variance prioritisation

finding: The genetic variant rs67492154 was associated with TFPI levels and colocalized with all-stroke genetic associations, indicating a shared causal variant. This finding suggested that the effect of TFPI on stroke outcomes might be mediated through its genetic influence.
title: Genetically predicted levels of the human plasma proteome and risk of stroke: a Mendelian Randomization study

finding: The SNP rs141421624, found intronic in the XPO1 gene, was significantly associated with progression to H&Y 3 or greater and was identified as a significant eQTL for multiple genes, indicating its influence on gene expression.
title: Genome-wide determinants of mortality and motor progression in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The intronic variant rs926416351 showed a P-value of 4.07×10^-6, linking it with UC via gene-based tests.
title: Genome-wide analysis of individual coding variants and HLA-II-associated self-immunopeptidomes in ulcerative colitis

finding: The SNP rs1861412 showed a positive association with Body Mass Index (BMI). This finding aligned with the context of metabolic traits and further supported the investigation of its role in relation to disorders such as insomnia.
title: Exploiting collider bias to apply two-sample summary data Mendelian randomization methods to one-sample individual level data

finding: The SNP rs11694915, located in the IL1R1 gene, was part of three novel genome-wide significant loci identified for polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) in the analysis of 8,156 PMR cases.
title: Modifiable risk factors and inflammation-related proteins in polymyalgia rheumatica: genome-wide meta-analysis and Mendelian randomisation

finding: The SNP rs4988235, located in the MCM6 gene, was rigorously assessed in the context of its association with colorectal cancer. The analysis indicated that genetically predicted milk intake, for which this SNP serves as a proxy, was inversely associated with the risk of colorectal cancer, colon cancer, and rectal cancer, showcasing relative risk (RR) values of 0.60, 0.60, and 0.49 respectively per 200 g/day of dairy milk intake. This relationship highlighted the protective effect of dairy consumption, largely attributed to the calcium content, among populations of European ancestry.
title: Diet-wide analyses for risk of colorectal cancer: prospective study of 12,250 incident cases among 543,000 women in the UK

finding: SNP rs2972144, located in the IRS1 locus, was highlighted as one of the shared SNPs with significant involvement in the relationship between type 2 diabetes and depression, particularly impacting gene expression in adipose tissue.
title: Bi-directional Mendelian randomization and multi-phenotype GWAS show causality and shared pathophysiology between depression and type 2 diabetes

finding: The rs4852714 variant was linked to a decreased expression of the gene CD207 in skin, while showing increased expression in myeloid dendritic cells (DCs). This finding underscored the role of skin-resident dendritic cells as potential contributors to increased risk of atopic dermatitis.
title: Multi-ancestry Genome-Wide Association Meta-Analysis Identifies Novel Loci in Atopic Dermatitis

finding: rs73104290, located in the SP140 gene, was found to be 4824 times more frequent in UKB-AFR (0.07) compared to UKB-EUR (1.46 x 10^-5, p = 8.6 x 10^-188), indicating a significant population-specific variant.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: The lead SNP rs114686503 associated with Glycated haemoglobin (HbA1c) was found to be 425.91 times more frequent in UKB-AFR than UKB-EUR, indicating its population-specific relevance to metabolic traits.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: Also associated with metabolic traits and part of strong LD with rs114686503, the variant rs75763409 had a notable frequency difference favoring UKB-AFR over UKB-EUR.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: Variant rs7557333 was part of the cluster linked to Glycated haemoglobin and had significant frequency differences between populations, similar to rs114686503.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: The SNP rs115457386 showed significant frequency discrepancies like its nearby variants, indicative of its joint relevance for metabolic study.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: This SNP was found near the GLI2 gene on chromosome 2. It was positively correlated with conversion, showing a combined meta-analysis HR of 3.74 and a p-value of 5.4 x 10^-10.
title: Genetic Factors Associated with Prostate Cancer Conversion from Active Surveillance to Treatment

finding: The SNP rs34799259 was reported as the leading SNP of one of the four distinct loci identified in the European ancestry sub-analysis, located in ARHGAP15 on chromosome 2, and had previously been suggestive of significance in the multi-ancestry analysis.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Traumatic Brain Injury in U.S. Military Veterans Enrolled in the VA Million Veteran Program

finding: The SNP rs1320139 was identified as a proxy variant for rs34799259 in the context of the ARHGAP15 gene, and it was found to be nominally significant in the replication study.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Traumatic Brain Injury in U.S. Military Veterans Enrolled in the VA Million Veteran Program

finding: As the SNP most strongly associated with LVMI, rs2255167 was located at the TTN locus. Previous research has documented its association with LVM and with familial cardiomyopathy, indicating its critical role in cardiac muscle function.
title: Clinical and Genetic Associations of Deep Learning-Derived Cardiac Magnetic Resonance-Based Left Ventricular Mass

finding: The study referenced highlighted the importance of the SNP rs13010047 in relation to recurrent glioblastoma. It suggested that understanding the molecular landscape of glioblastoma, including specific SNPs like rs13010047, could inform new treatment perspectives. This finding related to the broader context of treatment efficacy and patient outcomes in glioblastoma, underscoring the relevance of genetic markers in tailoring therapies for better management of the disease.
title: Data-driven extraction of unstructured electronic health records to evaluate glioblastoma treatment patterns

finding: This SNP was identified in the context of anxiety as it was part of four novel loci associated with anxiety. It was intronic within the NPPC gene and indicated functional significance due to a high CADD score.
title: Identification of Novel Genomic Loci for Anxiety and Extensive Genetic Overlap with Psychiatric Disorders

finding: Identified in shared loci between anxiety and bipolar disorder as well as schizophrenia, this SNP indicates genetic overlap among these psychiatric conditions.
title: Identification of Novel Genomic Loci for Anxiety and Extensive Genetic Overlap with Psychiatric Disorders

finding: This SNP was part of multiple shared loci between anxiety and schizophrenia, supporting the genetic overlap between these disorders.
title: Identification of Novel Genomic Loci for Anxiety and Extensive Genetic Overlap with Psychiatric Disorders

finding: The SNP rs78786199, found on chromosome 2 in an intergenic region, was also significantly associated with lower APE scores in breast cancer patients, with a p-value of 1.925×10⁻⁸. Carriers of the minor allele showed increased risk for cognitive decline compared to non-carriers, distinct from control individuals.
title: Genetic variants associated with longitudinal cognitive performance in older breast cancer patients and controls

finding: This variant, rs143578296, located at 2p25.3 upstream of MYT1L, was found to have an odds ratio of 1.99 (95% CI: 1.49-2.66; P=2.8×10^-6) in the discovery dataset. It achieved genome-wide significance in a trans-ancestry meta-analysis with an OR of 2.05 (95% CI: 1.59-2.65; P=4.5×10^-8), thereby demonstrating its positive association with DM risk.
title: Trans-ancestral genetic study of diabetes mellitus risk in survivors of childhood cancer: a report from the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort and the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study

finding: The SNP rs4664308, located in the PLA2R1 gene, was similarly linked to an elevated risk of minimal change nephrotic syndrome (MN) among participants in the UK Biobank. Individuals homozygous for the high-risk allele A exhibited a notable incidence rate of MN.
title: Membranous Nephropathy in the UK Biobank

finding: The index variant rs4245791 in ABCG8 was associated with genetically predicted decreased risk of cholelithiasis. This variant was previously linked to high risk of gallstone disease and high cholesterol absorption, indicating its critical role in lipid metabolism.
title: Implicating genes, pleiotropy and sexual dimorphism at blood lipid loci through multi-ancestry meta-analysis

finding: The SNP rs3861561 was identified as one of the 350 discriminating variants associated with refractive astigmatism, mutated within the NRXN1 gene, a component of the Neurexins and neuroligins pathway implicated in autism and cognitive disorders. This association highlighted the genetic links between astigmatism, cognitive functions, and developmental disorders.
title: A novel computational methodology for GWAS multi-locus analysis based on graph theory and machine learning
