finding: The G allele at rs147959551 was associated with decreased sedentary time at night and reduced minutes identified as sleep based on heart rate measurements. This SNP was enriched in individuals with depressive disorder, highlighting its connection to sleep disruptions, which are increasingly recognized as common features across various adolescent psychopathologies.
title: Digital phenotyping from wearables using AI characterizes psychiatric disorders and identifies genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs6741418 was associated with the glutaminase (GLS) gene region, where allele-specific expression related to this SNP was demonstrated. This study indicated that GLS expression was downregulated in the duodenal biopsies of children with untreated coeliac disease (CD). The association of rs6741418 with GLS added to the understanding of how genetic factors may contribute to metabolic alterations related to CD, particularly in the context of energy metabolism and the potential risk for diseases like type 2 diabetes and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
title: INTESTINAL GLUCONEOGENESIS IS DOWNREGULATED IN PAEDIATRIC PATIENTS WITH COELIAC DISEASE

finding: The SNP rs11681562 was recognized for its cross-ancestry genome-wide significant association driven by both European and African samples, with a z-score of -5.67 and a p-value of 1.4×10^-8. This variant is located in a genomic region with high linkage disequilibrium and has been previously associated with multiple phenotypes related to human cortical development.
title: Gene Discovery and Biological Insights into Anxiety Disorders from a Multi-Ancestry Genome-wide Association Study of >1.2 Million Participants

finding: Associated with F-ANOV, rs72827480 showed an odds ratio of 0.905 and colocalized with a testis-eQTL for INHBB, which regulates hormone secretion and ovarian follicle development.
title: Genome-wide analyses identify 21 infertility loci and over 400 reproductive hormone loci across the allele frequency spectrum

finding: With a beta value of 0.0163 and p-value of 3.79E-08, rs12611602 was reported to impact testosterone levels, implicating its relevance to fertility mechanisms.
title: Genome-wide analyses identify 21 infertility loci and over 400 reproductive hormone loci across the allele frequency spectrum

finding: The variant rs4148323, also known as UGT1A1*6, exhibited a 21-fold enrichment in Finland compared to non-Finnish Europeans. Its minor allele frequency was reported as 4.2% in Finns versus only 0.2% in non-Finnish Europeans. This variant has been implicated in increased toxicity of irinotecan, highlighting its significance in pharmacogenetics within this population.
title: Implementation of CYP2D6 copy-number imputation panel and frequency of key pharmacogenetic variants in Finnish individuals with a psychotic disorder

finding: The proxy variant rs887829 was used to estimate the frequency of the UGT1A1*28 variant in Finns. It demonstrated an increased frequency compared to the rest of Europe, indicating a higher prevalence of UGT1A1 poor metabolizers in Finland, which is essential in considering therapy involving irinotecan.
title: Implementation of CYP2D6 copy-number imputation panel and frequency of key pharmacogenetic variants in Finnish individuals with a psychotic disorder

finding: The SNP rs78529201 was identified as a significant risk factor for peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the Dominican population, with a 37.2% risk of the disease in heterozygous carriers compared to a 13.3% risk in non-carriers, demonstrating an odds ratio (OR) of 3.88 and a highly significant p-value (<1.95×10^-5). This SNP fell within the lincRNA LINC00607, which is crucial for regulating vascular processes.
title: Admixture Mapping of Peripheral Artery Disease in a Dominican Population Reveals a Novel Risk Locus on 2q35

finding: The SNP rs6715570 also changed NKX2-5 DNA binding, increasing its binding activity with the alternate allele. This variant was identified as influencing the expression of the gene BARD1 in the heart, which has been linked with developmental delays and is also implicated in cardiovascular risks.
title: Prioritizing Cardiovascular Disease-Associated Variants Altering NKX2-5 Binding through an Integrative Computational Approach

finding: A missense variant in CTLA4 was linked to increased risk of thyrotoxicosis, indicating potential therapeutic implications.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: The SNP rs11889341 located in the STAT4 gene was found to have a genome-wide significant association with primary antiphospholipid syndrome (PAPS), with a p-value of 1.39×10−9 and odds ratio (OR) of 0.61. This association demonstrated a consistent effect across five analyzed cohorts and had previously been linked to other autoimmune conditions, suggesting its broader relevance in autoimmunity.
title: A genome-wide association study suggests new susceptibility loci for primary antiphospholipid syndrome

finding: The variant rs886044536, located in the TTN gene, was noted to be a deletion (c.93396_93400del AGCTT) which resulted in the same amino-acid change as variants in ClinVar. This deletion caused a frameshift, leading to comparable functional effects. The TTN gene, linked to major phenotype implications, was among the actionable variants that were identified in the study.
title: Identification of actionable genetic variants in 4,198 Scottish volunteers from the Viking Genes research cohort and implementation of return of results

finding: rs28617484 was identified as the second strongest association for measles virus antibodies (P = 3.5×10^-8, β = -0.51), located between LINC01920 and LINC02612 on chromosome 2q23.3. Similar to rs506576, there was no replication possible in UK Biobank due to lack of data.
title: Genetic analyses of common infections in the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children cohort

finding: At the BIN1 locus, rs72838287 was identified as an emVar linked to increased expression of BIN1 through enhancer activity demonstrated via MPRA and eQTLs.
title: Deciphering the functional impact of Alzheimer’s Disease-associated variants in resting and proinflammatory immune cells

finding: This SNP was associated with Apo B, a protein identified to have a potential causal role in myocardial infarction (MI) risk based on proteome-wide Mendelian randomization.
title: Proteome-wide Mendelian Randomization Analysis Identified Potential Drug Targets for Myocardial Infarction

finding: This SNP was similarly linked with Apo B, reinforcing its relevance as a protein that potentially contributes to MI risk.
title: Proteome-wide Mendelian Randomization Analysis Identified Potential Drug Targets for Myocardial Infarction

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with time until relapse (TR) during acamprosate treatment, demonstrating a significant p-value of 3.1E-09, highlighting its importance as a predictor of treatment response.
title: Genetic Contributions to Alcohol Use Disorder Treatment Outcomes: A Genome-wide Pharmacogenomics Study

finding: This SNP in the BRE gene was associated with THR in the full cohort analysis, presenting a significant p-value of 1.6E-08 and suggesting that carrying the minor allele increases the risk of relapse to heavy drinking by 1.5 times.
title: Genetic Contributions to Alcohol Use Disorder Treatment Outcomes: A Genome-wide Pharmacogenomics Study

finding: This SNP demonstrated a strong association with circulating vitamin K1 levels, providing evidence for its relevance in warfarin's drug target validation and stroke risk reduction.
title: An Informatics Consult approach for generating clinical evidence for treatment decisions

finding: Identified as a cis-eQTL for SERPINE2, this SNP represents the first report of genetic association evidence at SERPINE2 and has implications in thrombin inhibition.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS for venous thromboembolism identifies novel loci followed by experimental validation in zebrafish

finding: The SNP rs183868412 was identified as significantly associated with an increased risk of invasive bacterial disease in Kenyan children, with an odds ratio (OR) of 2.21 (95% CI 1.75-2.79, p = 2.42 × 10^-11) across multiple studies. This finding was characteristic of various bacterial pathogens including gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, and independent of malaria risk. The presence of the risk allele (T) at this SNP was associated with modified splicing of the BIRC6 gene in stimulated monocytes, which was linked to the regulation of apoptosis and autophagy, indicating its role in the pathogenesis of sepsis.
title: BIRC6 modifies risk of invasive bacterial infection in Kenyan children

finding: The SNP rs56326533 was identified as a strong association located upstream of the SPATS2L gene, which has been linked to atrial fibrillation and QT-interval traits. This association aligned with known HF risk factors such as arrhythmias.
title: Multi-ancestry Multivariate Genome-Wide Analysis Highlights the Role of Common Genetic Variation in Cardiac Structure, Function, and Heart Failure-related Traits

finding: The rare missense variant in APOB at position chr2:21229160:C:T was classified as an FH variant despite being marked with 'conflicting interpretations of pathogenicity' in ClinVar. This decision was based on prior observations and the findings from this study, suggesting its involvement in familial hypercholesterolemia, which implicates it in increased risk for coronary artery disease.
title: Coronary Artery Disease Risk of Familial Hypercholesterolemia Genetic Variants Independent of Historical Cholesterol Exposure

finding: The SNP rs1191684 in the PAX8 locus was identified in Europeans and reliably replicated in a cohort of African-American individuals with a significance level of p = 9.3 × 10^-4, indicating its association with sleep duration.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide analysis identifies common genetic variants for self-reported sleep duration and shared genetic effects

finding: The minor allele of rs6737318 in the PAX8 locus exhibited a consistent effect size across various cohorts, showing higher minutes of sleep duration per allele in the EUR cohort (2.46 min/allele) and significant association in the African cohort (7.86 min/allele, p = 7.3 × 10^-4), suggesting its strong influence on sleep duration.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide analysis identifies common genetic variants for self-reported sleep duration and shared genetic effects

finding: The rs7556815 SNP located in the PAX8 locus was consistently associated with sleep duration across different ancestral groups, showing sign concordance and indicating its transferability for sleep duration traits.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide analysis identifies common genetic variants for self-reported sleep duration and shared genetic effects

finding: Located on chromosome 2 at 2q33.1, this eQTL tied to PLCL1 was implicated in autism spectrum disorder, presenting a connection to neurodevelopmental traits.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: The SNP rs17235409 in SLC11A1 demonstrated a significant interaction with the L4-Ugandan lineage, showing a meta p-value of 0.0002. This interaction indicated that carriers of the ancestral allele (GG) experienced increased severity of TB when infected with the new Ugandan lineage, highlighting the potential for coevolution effects between host genetics and pathogen lineage.
title: Interaction between host genes and M. tuberculosis lineage can affect tuberculosis severity: evidence for coevolution

finding: The SNP rs34032897 was located 36 kbp downstream of PAX3 at locus 2q36.1. It was confirmed to participate in regulatory activity affecting facial traits, specifically nasion characteristics.
title: Novel genetic loci affecting facial shape variation in humans

finding: The SNP rs2855266 was found in the 2q36.1 region and showed significant enhancer activity related to PAX3, influencing the morphological traits of the nasion.
title: Novel genetic loci affecting facial shape variation in humans

finding: The SNP rs13410020 from the 2q36.1 PAX3 locus demonstrated a strong association with enhancer activity as shown in the luciferase assays, impacting facial morphology significantly.
title: Novel genetic loci affecting facial shape variation in humans

finding: The SNP rs17705608 in the TANK gene was associated with breast cancer risk, where TANK was found to be involved in TNF-mediated signal transduction. The findings suggested that this SNP contributed to the inflammatory signaling pathway which plays a role in early recurrence of triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) post-neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC).
title: Integration of multi-omics data shows downregulation of mismatch repair, purin, and tublin pathways in AR-negative triple-negative chemotherapy-resistant breast tumors

finding: The SNP rs7309 in the TANK gene was similarly associated with breast cancer risk. It was highlighted that TANK operates through the NF-κB signaling pathway, which is crucial for inflammation modulation in TNBC. The association of these SNPs with breast cancer suggested their potential role in influencing recurrence-free disease outcomes following NAC.
title: Integration of multi-omics data shows downregulation of mismatch repair, purin, and tublin pathways in AR-negative triple-negative chemotherapy-resistant breast tumors

finding: The T allele frequency in rs3827760 (EDAR) in Amami-Oshima island (0.385) was significantly higher than in the Hondo cluster (0.222, P < 0.001) and not significantly different from the Ryukyu cluster (0.398, P = 0.426). In Kikai island, the T allele frequency (0.647) was significantly higher than in all other populations (P = 0.005 for Amami-Oshima island, P = 0.004 for Ryukyu cluster, P < 0.001 for Hondo cluster). This SNP is associated with traits such as thicker hair, straighter hair, and high density of sweat glands.
title: Genetic lineage of the Amami islanders inferred from classical genetic markers

finding: This SNP was flagged as newly significant in the Flexible cFDR analysis and validated in the larger dataset.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: The SNP rs6739323, identified as a risk allele for coronary artery disease (CAD), was associated with lower expression of the gene LTBP1 in cultured human smooth muscle cells and human aortic tissue. This finding was significant as it confirmed the role of LTBP1 expression in different cell types, particularly native contractile smooth muscle cells in the coronary layer and fibromyocytes in the fibrous neointima. The study suggested that elevated LTBP1 expression in certain plaques might indicate a protective role, highlighting its importance in the progression of atherosclerosis.
title: Integrative single-cell meta-analysis reveals disease-relevant vascular cell states and markers in human atherosclerosis

finding: The rs13004845 tamVar was associated with splicing changes where the reference allele exhibited splicing at 57% efficiency due to a strong 3' AG splice site, while the alternate G-to-A substitution abolished this splice site, leading to no splicing of the alt allele. This change corresponded to a 28% decrease in expression of the reference allele as measured by the Griesemer MPRA.
title: U-rich elements drive pervasive cryptic splicing in 3’ UTR massively parallel reporter assays

finding: The SNP rs116175783 was associated with intelligence and found to be lying on the intron of the TBR1 gene. It exhibited interaction with the promoter of the SLC4A10 gene in oligodendrocyte precursor cells. The SLC4A10 gene is also associated with intellectual disability (mental retardation), suggesting a potential connection between rs116175783 and disorders related to intelligence, although the specific link was not previously established in this cell type.
title: Improving chromatin-interaction prediction using single-cell open-chromatin profile and making insight about the cis-regulatory landscape of the human brain

finding: The SNP rs1344706 was reported as a psychosis risk variant that altered the expression of the gene ZNF804A in the human brain. This variant was associated with risks for schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and major depressive disorder, indicating its relevance in the development of these psychiatric conditions.
title: Schizophrenia risk gene ZNF804A controls ribosome localization and synaptogenesis in developing human neurons

finding: The SNP rs3795859 was reported to regulate the skipping of exon 35 in LRPPRC across 14 tissues. In a minigene assay, the T allele of rs3795859 was shown to increase the exclusion of exon 35 in HeLa and HEK293T cell lines.
title: Junction-skipping regulation in complex disease

finding: The variant rs28445040 was identified in a fine-mapping effort, showing it regulated the skipping of the 7th exon in SP140. It was determined to have a posterior probability of 39% in lymphocytes, suggesting its potential role as a causal variant for inflammatory bowel disease.
title: Junction-skipping regulation in complex disease

finding: The SNP rs10197004 was identified as significant in a study by Turley et al. (2018) and was associated with lipid-related molecules such as LDL receptor-related protein 1B (LRP1B), highlighting its role in the genetic basis for wellbeing.
title: The association between metabolite concentrations and wellbeing in adults

finding: The rs1275533 variant, which results in the amino acid change D5G, was identified in patients suffering from osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ) or atypical femoral fractures (AFF). It was shown to be associated with differential responses to nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates (N-BPs), as patients with this variant exhibited cellular hypersensitivity to N-BPs, suggesting a crucial role in the pharmacological response relevant to osteoporosis treatment.
title: ATRAID, a genetic factor that regulates the action of nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates on bone

finding: The rs11556163 variant, resulting in the amino acid change G32R, was also found in ONJ and AFF patients, indicating its presence alongside rs1275533 in the patient cases. This variant was linked to impaired responses to N-BPs, further implicating its significance in cellular sensitivity to these medications and highlighting its importance in studies focusing on drug efficacy and safety in osteoporosis management.
title: ATRAID, a genetic factor that regulates the action of nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates on bone

finding: The SNP rs13010035 was positively identified as a significant factor in the metabolic reprogramming of rheumatoid arthritis synovial fibroblasts (RASFs). This reprogramming involved a shift in ATP production from oxidative to glycolytic pathways, which was identified through the dynamics modeled in the study. The context of the finding is critical as it relates to RASFs' adaptation to a hypoxic environment and their ability to provide necessary metabolic intermediates to surrounding inflammatory cells, paralleling similar mechanisms observed in tumor microenvironments.
title: Metabolic Reprogramming in Rheumatoid Arthritis Synovial Fibroblasts: a Hybrid Modeling Approach

finding: This variant is found within the ATOH8 gene and was significantly associated with an increase in AAA prevalence, showing a p-value of 9.06x10^-9 and an OR of 2.714. ATOH8 plays a role in myogenesis and is implicated in endothelial cell function.
title: Analysis of UK Biobank Cohort Reveals Novel Insights for Thoracic and Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms

finding: Analyzed within the context of neuroendocrine lung cancer mouse models as per Lorz et al. (2020), this SNP implicated in tumor modeling demonstrated relevance in understanding the biology and treatment responses of neuroendocrine lung cancers.
title: Druggable Growth Dependencies and Tumor Evolution Analysis in Patient-Derived Organoids of Neuroendocrine Cancer

finding: The SNP rs13030524 was found to be connected to CDK4/6 inhibition and its role in reprogramming mitochondrial metabolism in BRAF(V600) melanoma, illustrating its importance in cancer metabolic reprogramming.
title: CDK4 inactivation balances resistance to apoptosis with heightened metabolic sensitivity in triple negative breast cancer cells

finding: The study indicated that the stop variant rs199689137 (p.R446Ter) in the ABCG5 gene was associated with elevated levels of LDL-C. Specifically, heterozygous carriers of this variant had significantly increased LDL-C levels of 24.7 mg/dL compared to non-carriers. Additionally, this variant was linked to a two-fold increased risk of coronary artery disease (CAD), with an odds ratio of 2.06, thereby demonstrating its potential significance as a contributor to lipid metabolism and cardiovascular risk.
title: Heterozygous ATP-binding Cassette Transporter G5 Gene Deficiency and Risk of Coronary Artery Disease

finding: The eQTL rs1518367 was linked to reduced transcript levels of SF3B1 in fetal cortex, indicating selective regulatory effects pertinent to ASD pathology.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: The T allele of rs182549 reduced the abundance of species Bifidobacterium adolescentis and Bifidobacterium longum and was implicated in the dominant inheritance of lactase persistence in adults. Associations were replicated across various taxa, highlighting the broad impact of the LCT locus on microbiome composition.
title: Effect of host genetics on the gut microbiome in 7,738 participants of the Dutch Microbiome Project

finding: As a perfect proxy of rs182549, rs4988235 was linked to lactase persistence, confirming its role in modifying the gut microbiome, particularly the abundance of Bifidobacterium species.
title: Effect of host genetics on the gut microbiome in 7,738 participants of the Dutch Microbiome Project

finding: The SNP rs12990970 was identified as a potential causative variant for type 1 diabetes (T1D), located in a Treg super-enhancer and flanking an active transcription start site (TSS). It engaged in long-range interactions primarily influencing the CD28 gene, which is essential for Treg function.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: The SNP rs3087243 was identified as a candidate variant in T1D and showed potential involvement in regulatory pathways affecting immune response, specifically linked to the gene ABI2.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: This SNP was identified to potentially disrupt transcription factor binding, thus affecting Treg function in T1D.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: CXCR1 rs2234671 was linked to overall response in patients treated for colorectal cancer, aiding in the assessment of treatment effectiveness.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: CXCR2 rs2230054 was linked to overall response in treatments related to colorectal cancer, contributing to understanding pharmacogenomic influences.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: The SNP rs1658810 was positively associated with Schizophrenia and located in the intron of the C2orf69 gene, which plays a role in the immune and central nervous systems. It exhibited strong statistical significance in both GWAS and eQTL analyses, showing associations with C2orf47 and LINC01792, among others, in various datasets. Functional studies using massively parallel reporter assays confirmed that rs1658810 showed allelic differences in driving gene expression in specific cell lines. Furthermore, its neighborhood was defined as a risk locus for Alzheimer’s disease (AD), where prioritization strategies revealed that top-ranked variants were significantly correlated with changes in Braak staging, indicating its relevance for both AD and Schizophrenia.
title: DeepPerVar: a multimodal deep learning framework for functional interpretation of genetic variants in personal genome

finding: Associated with increased Akkermansia abundance, rs12472313 suggests that this SNP may have significant implications for colorectal cancer risk through its genetic influence on microbiota.
title: Gut microbiota composition in colorectal cancer patients is genetically regulated

finding: The study identified the selection at the LCT locus during the historical period in European populations. The causal allele, rs4988235, was absent prior to the arrival of Steppe Pastoralists in the Bronze Age, thus it could not have been under selection at that time. The results showed a rapid increase in frequency of rs4988235 only during the historical period, aligning with findings from other ancient DNA studies.
title: Understanding natural selection in Holocene Europe using multi-locus genotype identity scans

finding: The rs200302685 variant in the HOXD12 gene was assessed as damaging, although its exact role was unknown. HOXD12 is part of the homeobox family involved in the regulation of embryonic development and has been implicated in the maintenance and control of HIV-1 latency.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing-based Characterization of Human Genome Variation and Mutation Burden in Botswana

finding: This SNP was linked to KYNU levels, an enzyme significant in NAD biosynthesis from tryptophan. Its association with metabolic syndrome components such as HDL and triglycerides highlighted its potential role in obesity-related metabolic pathways.
title: A large-scale multivariate pQTL study sheds light on the genetic architecture of obesity

finding: The UGT1A1 rs887829 genotype C/C was associated with significantly higher glucose concentrations during glucose tolerance tests after olanzapine treatment. This suggests that this SNP may play a role in the drug's impact on glucose metabolism.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: This variant was characterized as fixed in the Denisovan, while all Neanderthals had the human reference allele. It was associated with decreased hemoglobin levels in Tibetans and predicted to create a donor gain, strengthening a 5' splice site, leading to NMD.
title: Resurrecting the Alternative Splicing Landscape of Archaic Hominins using Machine Learning

finding: The SNP rs13020307 was part of research focusing on 3D cell cultures as models to examine extracellular vesicles in cancer. The findings indicated that this SNP impacted the biological mechanisms related to EV production and their roles in advancing cancer pathology.
title: Investigating the impact of fibroblast proximity to a tumor on fibroblast extracellular vesicle production utilizing 3D bioprinted stromal models

finding: The rs1375493 variant in the ITGA4 locus was one of the top candidates identified using monocyte QTL data, achieving the highest posterior probability of fine-mapping among all variants studied (PP=0.49). It was located within the C/EBPβ binding peak and implicates strong regulatory potential associated with IBS.
title: Genetic associations at regulatory phenotypes improve fine-mapping of causal variants for twelve immune-mediated diseases

finding: The rs6753933 variant at the RBMS1 locus was found to colocalise with a GWAS hit for lymphocyte count. This was supported by effect sizes and confidence intervals derived from multiple eQTL Catalogue datasets, indicating a strong relationship between the eQTL in CD4+ T cells and lymphocyte count.
title: eQTL Catalogue: a compendium of uniformly processed human gene expression and splicing QTLs

finding: The genetic effects on the expression of the IGKV1-27 gene varied across puberty stages in males, with regulation disappearing by late puberty. The presence of hormone response elements near IGKV1-27 suggested that hormonal changes during puberty likely influenced this genetic effect.
title: Analysis of transcriptional changes in the immune system associated with pubertal development in a longitudinal cohort of children with asthma

finding: The sentinel cis pQTL for ERBB4 associated with higher ERBB4 levels and showed a potential link to lower BMI, highlighting its relevance in obesity-related contexts.
title: Large-scale comparison of immunoassay- and aptamer-based plasma proteomics through genetics and disease

finding: A variant highly correlated with the rs6735267 (cis pQTL for ERBB4) associated with lower BMI, suggesting its implications in metabolic regulation.
title: Large-scale comparison of immunoassay- and aptamer-based plasma proteomics through genetics and disease

finding: The SNP rs34681162 was associated with the ADAM17 gene, known for its role in mediating coronary arteriole dilation. This association contributes to our understanding of genetic predispositions to hypertension.
title: Chromatin interaction maps of human arterioles reveal new mechanisms for the genetic regulation of blood pressure

finding: The SNP rs28445040 was identified in Crohn's disease (CD) patients and associated with the loss of SP140, a protein implicated in immune regulation and chromatin modification. This SNP's presence was linked to heightened genome instability and compromised immune cell function.
title: Identification of topoisomerase as a precision-medicine target in chromatin reader SP140-driven Crohn’s disease

finding: Similar to rs28445040, the SNP rs6716753 was investigated in the context of Crohn's disease (CD) and associated with the dysfunctional presence of SP140. Its impact suggested regulatory roles of SP140 and potential therapeutic targets for modulation of immune response.
title: Identification of topoisomerase as a precision-medicine target in chromatin reader SP140-driven Crohn’s disease

finding: The SNP rs7423615 was examined in lymphoblastoid cells and homozygous variants exhibited loss-of-function in SP140. This result underscored the direct involvement of SP140 variants in affecting topoisomerase activity, leading to implications in chromatin regulation and immune disease.
title: Identification of topoisomerase as a precision-medicine target in chromatin reader SP140-driven Crohn’s disease

finding: The deleterious variant rs41288783 in APOB was associated with higher LDL-C levels. Despite it not being previously linked to lipid traits, this study identified its interaction with alcohol consumption on lipid levels.
title: Role of Rare and Low Frequency Variants in Gene-Alcohol Interactions on Plasma Lipid Levels

finding: The intronic variant rs60873293 was associated with a single sensorimotor RSN, as identified in the GWAS study by Elliott et al., 2018. This finding underscored its specific role in the genetic architecture of BOLD amplitude measures.
title: Shared genetic influences on resting-state functional networks of the brain

finding: The lead SNP rs6737318 was identified in the multivariate GWAS analysis and was significantly associated with a genetic factor (F2) that influenced 21 SNPs related to four sensorimotor networks (SN5-8). This SNP was reported with a genome-wide significance level (P = 2.15E-09) and its nearest gene was PAX8, suggesting an important genetic connection to heritable aspects of brain function.
title: Shared genetic influences on resting-state functional networks of the brain

finding: The SNP rs2058622 was identified as a high-effect SNP for eczema and was located within an intron of the IL18R1 gene. This candidate SNP overlapped a cis-regulatory element, enhancing IL18RAP expression, particularly in the CD4 helper T cell cluster. The alternative allele increased chromatin accessibility by creating a strong RUNX motif and also had strong associations with IL18RAP expression in blood, supporting its significance in eczema pathogenesis.
title: Integrated single-cell chromatin and transcriptomic analyses of human scalp reveal etiological insights into genetic risk for hair and skin disease

finding: The SNP rs72966077 was identified as a high-effect SNP associated with androgenetic alopecia (AGA) and was found to be located immediately downstream of the WNT10A gene. It disrupted an ERG transcription factor motif in a keratinocyte-specific cis-regulatory element, indicating a role in WNT10A expression. The SNP was also implicated in acne vulgaris and highlighted the importance of the WNT-signaling pathway in contributing to AGA, particularly in dermal papilla and keratinocyte cells.
title: Integrated single-cell chromatin and transcriptomic analyses of human scalp reveal etiological insights into genetic risk for hair and skin disease

finding: The SNP rs3827760 in the EDAR gene, associated with thicker hair and shovel-shaped incisors phenotypes, showed Jomon-derived haplotype frequencies of 17.3% for the derived allele (thicker hair and shovel-shaped incisors) and 14.9% for the ancestral allele (thinner hair and non-shovel-shaped incisors) in mainland Japanese. The results suggest that the derived alleles in modern Japanese are likely inherited from the Jomon ancestry.
title: Comprehensive analysis of Japanese population history by detecting ancestry-marker polymorphisms without using ancestral genomic information

finding: This SNP was associated within the context of the joint analyses between MS and Crohn's disease (CD), contributing to the understanding of genetic associations.
title: Investigating the shared genetic architecture between multiple sclerosis and inflammatory bowel diseases

finding: The SNP rs17487792 was associated with significantly reduced BARD1 expression across 34 normal tissues, particularly in various nervous system tissues. Furthermore, tumor samples from children carrying the homozygous T risk allele (T/T genotype) exhibited a significantly higher burden of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) compared to those with the homozygous non-risk genotype (C/C). This association was more pronounced in high-risk neuroblastomas without MYCN amplification.
title: BARD1 germline variants induce haploinsufficiency and DNA repair defects in neuroblastoma

finding: The rs848293 locus was strongly associated with beat synchronization and was mapped at chromosome 2 near the VRK2 gene, which codes for a protein kinase expressed in the brain. This locus was located within a region previously linked to multiple neurological phenotypes.
title: Genome-wide association study of musical beat synchronization demonstrates high polygenicity

finding: This celiac disease-associated SNP connected to the ITGA4 promoter is expected to impact transcription factor binding, illustrating the functional consequences of autoimmunity-linked SNPs.
title: Dynamic chromatin architecture identifies new autoimmune-associated enhancers for IL2 and novel genes regulating CD4+ T cell activation

finding: This lactase persistence variant was found to be under positive selection, with CNN methods indicating that selection started at the beginning of the Bronze Age. The CNN provided better estimates for the selection parameters than previous ABC methods, specifically reducing confidence intervals by about 20-40%.
title: Deep estimation of the intensity and timing of selection from ancient genomes

finding: The SNP rs12713840 was identified as a significant genetic regulator of DNA replication timing. In the study, it was strongly associated in <italic>cis</italic> with variation in replication timing, influencing the initiation activity of replication. Genotype analysis at this SNP demonstrated that it was the main determinant of replication timing variation among individuals, showing marked differences in mean replication timing profiles based on genotype.
title: The Genetic Architecture of DNA Replication Timing in Human Pluripotent Stem Cells

finding: The SNP rs17013371 was found to be associated with lower hemolysis in stored human RBCs and RBC susceptibility to hemolysis upon osmotic insults. It was identified as the most common non-synonymous STEAP3 coding SNP and had an impact on the ferrireductase function of the enzyme, which is crucial for iron uptake in erythroid cells.
title: Ferroptosis regulates hemolysis in stored murine and human red blood cells

finding: The variant rs141086904 showed significant associations with multiple prostaglandins and oxylipins, especially HODEs, and was linked to increased susceptibility to hemolysis upon oxidative insults. It is positioned near the active site of STEAP3, affecting its enzymatic activity.
title: Ferroptosis regulates hemolysis in stored murine and human red blood cells

finding: SNP rs147820529 was correlated with increased susceptibility to hemolysis following oxidant insults and was part of the genetic variants list that impacted hemolysis in stored human RBCs, influencing overall RBC stability.
title: Ferroptosis regulates hemolysis in stored murine and human red blood cells

finding: The SNP rs4241281 was found in the intergenic region between CAVIN2 and TMEFF2 genes and exhibited a negative association with the genus Acinetobacter (p=9.13×10^-12). This genetic locus was also associated with the relative abundance of other microbes including Bosea and Acinetobacter johnsonii. Moreover, it correlated with several blood and urinary factors. The study indicated that individuals with the AA allele showed a stronger relationship between serum testosterone and Acinetobacter abundance.
title: Unraveling the impact of host genetics and factors on the urinary microbiome in a young population

finding: The SNP rs1260326 was positively associated with liver volume and colocalised with T2D, hypercholesterolemia, and multiple metabolic traits, indicating its relevance in these phenotypes and previously linked to NAFLD.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs7577758 had a significant association within the SLC40A1 gene, which is critical in iron absorption, and linked to iron homeostasis.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs115380467 showed a significant association with iron retention traits, reinforcing its established importance in iron metabolism.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs807624 was associated with average kidney volume and linked to biomarkers relevant for kidney function.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The univariate gge test identified rs888083 on chromosome 2, associated with triglycerides, as an independent locus not recognized by other methods.
title: A multivariate approach to joint testing of main genetic and gene-environment interaction effects

finding: The SNP CTLA4/rs41265961-G remained virtually constant in frequency across the populations, indicating its stable role in immune response despite geographical differences.
title: Hypothetical Human Immune Genome Complex Gradient May Help to Explain the Congenital Zika Symdrome Catastrophe in Brazil: A New Theory

finding: The variant rs2193495 was identified to be associated with reduced MPRA activity due to the creation of EOMES and MAZ binding sites, thereby potentially regulating the expression of T-box brain transcription factor 1 (TBR1), which is a gene linked to ASD.
title: Massively parallel characterization of psychiatric disorder-associated and cell-type-specific regulatory elements in the developing human cortex

finding: The rs7608034 SNP in the ALK gene was identified as a genome-wide significant locus associated with increased weight and sleep (↑WS) depression in analyses adjusted for BMI, with a beta coefficient of 1.14 (95% CI: 0.73-1.55) and a p-value of 3.09 x 10^-8.
title: Characterisation and Genetic Architecture of Major Depressive Disorder Subgroups Defined by Weight and Sleep Changes

finding: The SNP rs12617721, located in the intronic region of the gene INPP4A, was noted for its significant association with mood-incongruent psychotic bipolar disorder as reported in previous genome-wide association studies (GWAS). This finding highlighted its relevance in the context of glutamatergic pathways and suggested a potential role in schizophrenia due to the shared genetic basis observed in the multimember affected families studied.
title: Oligogenic rare variant contributions in schizophrenia and their convergence with genes harbouring de novo mutations in schizophrenia, autism and intellectual disability: Evidence from multiplex families

finding: The SNP rs4670221-G was associated with haematological alterations. This finding was significant with a p-value of 3 × 10^-10, highlighting its relevance to myeloid immune responses in the context of COVID-19.
title: Single cell RNA-seq uncovers the nuclear decoy lincRNA PIRAT as a regulator of systemic monocyte immunity during COVID-19

finding: The rs1010 polymorphism in the VAMP8 gene was associated with host susceptibility to pulmonary tuberculosis in a Chinese Han population. This finding highlighted a genetic predisposition influencing the response to the pathogenic challenge posed by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, indicating that specific genetic variations can affect the severity and susceptibility to infections.
title: Comparative analysis of macrophage post-translational modifications during intracellular bacterial pathogen infection

finding: The SNP rs13010143 was identified in the context of a study that performed a systematic review and meta-analysis focusing on non-small-cell lung cancer. This research examined sex-based differences in transcriptomic studies and highlighted the significance of this SNP in relation to these differences, suggesting a possible association with cancer susceptibility or progression based on sex.
title: MetaFun: Unveiling Sex-based Differences in Multiple Transcriptomic Studies through Comprehensive Functional Meta-analysis

finding: The G allele of rs6546891 was associated with a nominally increased risk of sPTB in European ancestry individuals (OR: 1.13, adjusted p-value: 5.4×10−5). This risk allele arose on the human lineage, while the protective allele (A) is ancestral and present across great apes. Significant conservation at this locus indicated a likely deleterious effect from disruptions in NAT8 or TET3, both genes linked to gestation and pregnancy outcomes.
title: Accounting for diverse evolutionary forces reveals the mosaic nature of selection on genomic regions associated with human preterm birth

finding: The rs6546894 variant contained a human-specific risk allele located in the 3' UTR of the TET3 gene. It exhibited strong evidence of long-term evolutionary conservation and was associated with changes in the gene expression of MGC10955 and NAT8 across various tissues.
title: Accounting for diverse evolutionary forces reveals the mosaic nature of selection on genomic regions associated with human preterm birth

finding: The rs10932774 variant, located in the intron of the PNKD gene, was associated with an increased risk of sPTB (OR: 1.11, adjusted p-value 8.85×10−5). It showed indications of balancing selection and was prevalent across populations. The variant was also linked with expression changes in multiple genes relevant to pregnancy.
title: Accounting for diverse evolutionary forces reveals the mosaic nature of selection on genomic regions associated with human preterm birth

finding: The rs1601328 variant linked to the PPFIA1 gene had significant associations with multiple tissue expressions and was suggestive of positive selection. It related to critical processes in placenta development and showed its importance in the context of sPTB.
title: Accounting for diverse evolutionary forces reveals the mosaic nature of selection on genomic regions associated with human preterm birth

finding: The SNP rs11336847 within the GCKR gene was confirmed as an established locus associated with HOMA-IR, indicating its influential role in insulin resistance.
title: Genetics of fasting indices of glucose homeostasis using GWIS unravels tight relationships with inflammatory markers

finding: The rs3827760 SNP, an A to G mutation associated with hair thickness, exhibited a derived allele that reached high frequency in East Asian and North American populations but was rare elsewhere. The study indicated that the direction of prediction error in location estimates was influenced by this genotype, with individuals carrying the G allele generally predicting east of their true geographical location. This effect was particularly notable in heterozygous populations, and the discrepancies were attributed to the prevalence of G allele haplotypes having closer relatives in eastern Eurasia, highlighting the impact of strong differentiation in this genomic region on geographical predictions.
title: Predicting Geographic Location from Genetic Variation with Deep Neural Networks

finding: The sentinel SNP rs10933431 was found to overlap a peak that was acetylated only in microglia but not in neurons or oligodendrocytes. This SNP was associated with significant GWAS p-values, indicating a strong linkage to late onset Alzheimer’s Disease (LOAD). It was noted that rs10933431 disrupts a binding motif for the paired box transcription factor Pax-5, which is vital for immune cell maturation, suggesting its involvement in altering regulatory function in immune cells.
title: Cell type-specific histone acetylation profiling of Alzheimer’s Disease subjects and integration with genetics

finding: The SNP rs4663105, located at the BIN1 locus, showed overlap with an acetylated peak in both microglia and oligodendrocytes but not in neurons. It was associated with high GWAS p-values suggesting it has a pivotal role in Alzheimer’s Disease risk. The SNP also had known expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) associations with BIN1 expression in whole blood and lymphoblastoid cells, indicating its potential role in regulating BIN1 expression related to AD.
title: Cell type-specific histone acetylation profiling of Alzheimer’s Disease subjects and integration with genetics

finding: Similar to rs4663105, the SNP rs6733839 was found to overlap with an acetylated peak active in both microglia and oligodendrocytes. It also demonstrated high GWAS p-values, reinforcing its association with Alzheimer’s Disease. This SNP was noted to influence BIN1 gene expression and overlapped DNase I hypersensitive sites, indicating a regulatory function in myeloid lineage cells, and a CRISPR-Cas9 deletion of the enhancer it overlaps altered BIN1 expression.
title: Cell type-specific histone acetylation profiling of Alzheimer’s Disease subjects and integration with genetics

finding: The SNP rs3827760 was identified by tangleGen as the main SNP responsible for distinguishing East Asian populations from other superpopulations in the tangles tree, thereby highlighting its critical role in population differentiation.
title: Inferring Ancestry with the Hierarchical Soft Clustering Approach tangleGen

finding: The SNP rs1562305 was associated with non-coding activity affecting cytokine production in response to C. albicans. This variant demonstrated its impact through interaction with genes IL36A and IL36G based on Hi-C data and was bound by several transcription factors. Its role was highlighted in the context of inflammatory and immune responses, specifically noted for its association with ulcerative colitis and diabetes mellitus type II.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variation in the Interleukin-1 pathway on human cytokine responses

finding: The variant rs895497 in IL36A was significantly linked to higher levels of IL-1β and IL-6 cytokine production in response to C. albicans stimulation. The alternative allele frequency was greater than the ancestral allele, indicating a positive association with increased cytokine production.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variation in the Interleukin-1 pathway on human cytokine responses

finding: The SNP rs6761276, also located in IL38, was found to be positively associated with enhanced production of IL-1β and IL-6 during C. albicans stimulation. Similar to rs895497, it exhibited a higher frequency for the alternative allele, correlating with greater cytokine responses.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variation in the Interleukin-1 pathway on human cytokine responses

finding: The variant rs6743376 in IL38 showed a significant relationship with increased IL-1β and IL-6 cytokine production following C. albicans stimulation. It was specifically noted that cytokine production was higher in individuals with the alternative allele compared to those with reference alleles.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variation in the Interleukin-1 pathway on human cytokine responses

finding: The SNP rs1279189246, which corresponds to the H478L mutation, was found to lead to decreased stability of the protein. This decrease in stability resulted in unstable amino acid interactions, potentially contributing to the pathogenesis of Woodhouse-Sakati syndrome.
title: In silico analysis of coding SNPs and 3′-UTR associated miRNAs in DCAF17 gene that may affect the regulation and pathogenesis of Woodhouse-Sakati Syndrome

finding: The SNP rs113983130 was found to be associated with a modifier haplotype (2ABEM1) in MSH2, correlating with decreased CAG expansion (p=3.7E-42) despite it lacking links to MSH2 expression in blood.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs4987188, a missense variant in the MSH2 region, was connected to intergenerational transmission of changes in repeat lengths, demonstrating its relevance in CAG repeat instability.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs79939438 formed part of a second modifier effect (2ABEM2) and was associated with increased CAG repeat expansion and MSH6 expression, indicating its complex role in Huntington's disease pathology.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs76405401 linked with distinguishing effects in the PMS1 region underlined the multifactorial nature of genetic modifiers.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs6434365 was noted for its role in the PMS1 region, where it contributed to comprehending the multifaceted genetic influence on Huntington's disease.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs193001369 was examined amongst others that accumulated in age at motor onset related effects, contributing to knowledge in genetic variations.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs17864672 correlated with data influencing the complexity underlying Huntington's disease modifier effects.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs2694642, located in the USP34 gene, was reported to regulate levels of axin and stabilize beta-catenin, affecting the Wnt signaling pathway, which is essential for leukemia stem cell development in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Iterative feature selection method to discover predictive variables and interactions for high-dimensional transplant genomic data

finding: The SNP rs385076 was identified as the lead variant within the NLRC4 locus, and it represented the smallest credible set in the FiniMOM analysis. It was also confirmed as the top variant in the replication GWAS, indicating its significant association with traits related to the NLRC4 locus.
title: Genetic fine-mapping from summary data using a non-local prior improves detection of multiple causal variants

finding: The analysis provided evidence of a significant connection between the development of cervical cancer (CC) and the rs5742909 polymorphism in the CTLA-4 gene among Asian populations. This finding was derived from a meta-analysis of 11 international studies involving 3899 cases of cervical cancer.
title: Checkpoint proteins in patients with precancer and cervical cancer

finding: At the MCM6/LCT locus, the derived allele related to lactase persistence began increasing in frequency around 6,000 years ago, indicating strong selection in dairy consumption contexts prior to the expansion of pastoralists.
title: The Selection Landscape and Genetic Legacy of Ancient Eurasians

finding: This SNP, associated with energy expenditure and metabolic disease, began rising in frequency approximately 12,000 years ago, suggesting it was an early adaptation to famine conditions.
title: The Selection Landscape and Genetic Legacy of Ancient Eurasians

finding: The SNP rs60977503 was identified as a predicted trans-eQTL in breast tissue. It overlapped with a GWAS hit in estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer and was linked to four target genes associated with breast cancer, including FAM183A, MUC4, HSPB6, and CCL28, emphasizing its role in breast cancer mechanisms.
title: Reverse regression increases power for detecting trans-eQTLs

finding: The rs4988235 SNP within the MCM6 gene was reported to be virtually absent (0%) in the WeRuHG individuals. This allele was observed to have a frequency of approximately 10% in the Fatyanovo Culture individuals, indicating a significant shift towards higher lactase persistence compared to the hunter-gatherer population.
title: Genetic ancestry changes in Stone to Bronze Age transition in the East European plain

finding: Similar to rs4988235, the rs182549 SNP located in the MCM6 gene was found to be absent in the WeRuHG individuals and had around 10% frequency in the Fatyanovo individuals. This suggested an increase in lactase persistence correlating with the adoption of farming practices.
title: Genetic ancestry changes in Stone to Bronze Age transition in the East European plain

finding: The SNP rs11554825 was associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis and ulcerative colitis (UC). This finding indicated a robust mutation analysis of the GPBAR1 receptor, which is a G protein-coupled receptor for secondary bile acids, highlighting its significance in the immune response and inflammatory processes associated with IBD.
title: A microbial derived bile acid acts as GPBAR1 agonist and RORγt inverse agonist and reverses inflammation in inflammatory bowel disease

finding: Originally assigned to the gene B3GNT2, the study provided evidence that rs10865331 actually implicated the promoter of COMMD1, a distal gene associated with NFkB signaling, detected in stimulated HaCaT and My-La cells.
title: Chromatin-based techniques map DNA interaction landscapes in psoriasis susceptibility loci and highlight KLF4 as a target gene in 9q31

finding: The variant rs4075111 was mapped to INPP5D in microglia from control subjects, demonstrating its involvement in this AD-related gene's regulation. Similar to rs10792831, the association was insignificant in microglia from AD patients, highlighting the context-dependent nature of its regulatory function in Alzheimer's disease.
title: Cell-type-specific mapping of enhancers and target genes from single-cell multimodal data

finding: The SNP rs6433311 was an sQTL for the DYNC1I2 gene, associated with an effect size of -1.174, which indicated exon exclusion. The G allele was linked to a predicted increase in HNRNPM binding affinity.
title: Profiling genetically driven alternative splicing across the Indonesian Archipelago

finding: The rs191148279 variant was linked to glycosylated hemoglobin A1c levels, indicating it is situated within a strong regulatory element affecting transcription.
title: Functional dissection of complex and molecular trait variants at single nucleotide resolution

finding: The indel mutation SNP rs115474479 was identified as a stop-gain mutation in the DNAH7 gene, which encodes a protein involved in ciliary function. This gene variant became significant because DNAH7 mutations have been associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), a condition that correlates with cholesteatoma.
title: Whole exome sequencing study identifies candidate loss of function variants and locus heterogeneity in familial cholesteatoma

finding: The SNP rs260690 located in the ectodysplasin A receptor (EDAR) gene exhibited the strongest signal in the PBS analysis with a value of 0.36. This gene is known to encode a transmembrane protein that interacts with the ectodysplasin A ligand, influencing morphological changes in traits such as tooth structure and hair thickness, demonstrating significant adaptive features in the Yi populations.
title: Distinguished biological adaptation architecture aggravated population differentiation of Tibeto-Burman-speaking people inferred from 500 whole-genome data from 39 populations

finding: In this study, the SNP rs182549 was identified as a perfect proxy for the functional LCT variant rs4988235 and was associated with the abundance of the genus Bifidobacterium. This association reached a genome-wide significance level with a p-value of 1.28×10⁻²⁰. It was noted that this association was age-dependent, being stronger in adults compared to younger individuals. The study highlighted that individuals homozygous for the CC genotype (rs182549) showed higher levels of Bifidobacterium in adults but not in younger cohorts.
title: Large-scale association analyses identify host factors influencing human gut microbiome composition

finding: The functional SNP rs4988235 in the LCT locus was shown to regulate lactose metabolism and was linked to the abundance of Bifidobacterium. This association was strongly supported, with a determined p-value of 1.28×10⁻²⁰, and highlighted the interaction between genetics and dairy consumption, particularly in those who are lactose intolerant.
title: Large-scale association analyses identify host factors influencing human gut microbiome composition

finding: This SNP was part of a block of 10 SNPs associated with the Peptococcaceae family, linked to gut inflammation markers. It had a significant association (p=1.42×10⁻⁹) showing a potential relationship between dietary habits and gut composition.
title: Large-scale association analyses identify host factors influencing human gut microbiome composition

finding: The SNP rs56063487 was identified as a splice eQTL for the CD8B gene, showing significant association with increased CD8-protein levels on CD8+ T cells, and providing insights into immune response modulation.
title: Gene expansions contributing to human brain evolution

finding: The SNP rs6547706 served as an eQTL for the CD8B gene, influencing protein levels in T cells, further demonstrating its role in the adaptive immune response, consistent with balancing selection observed in various ancestries.
title: Gene expansions contributing to human brain evolution

finding: rs2943641 was positively associated with M-HDL-P, L-HDL-P, XL-HDL-P, HDL-D, ApoA1, and HDL-C, and negatively associated with coronary artery disease (CAD). This finding suggested its potential protective role in CAD through its effects on HDL particle characteristics.
title: A Mendelian randomization study of the role of lipoprotein subfractions in coronary artery disease

finding: A 21 bp coding deletion was identified at rs527464858 in GIGYF2, a gene associated with receptor signaling, observed in both non-Hispanic white (NHW) and Caribbean Hispanic (CH) populations. This deletion segregated with AD status in multiple families, showing specific co-segregation in three NHW families and one Hispanic family.
title: A comparative study of structural variant calling strategies using the Alzheimer’s Disease Sequencing Project’s whole genome family data

finding: The SNP rs11686156, located on chromosome 2, was identified in a known allele-specific differential methylation region (ASDMR) in the GM12878 human cell line using the Methyl-SNP-seq technology. This study revealed that 47% of the identified ASDMRs were associated with SNPs directly affecting cytosine in CpG sites, indicating that this SNP plays a significant role in disrupting the methylation pattern of the affected CpG site and influencing adjacent regions. This finding highlighted the importance of CpG-SNPs in the context of DMR studies as they are crucial for the establishment of certain types of DMRs.
title: Methyl-SNP-seq reveals dual readouts of methylome and variome at molecule resolution

finding: The SNP rs288326, a non-synonymous SNP, had a posterior inclusion probability (PIP) of 0.96 for its association with height using the PolyFun + SuSiE method, whereas its PIP was only 0.35 when analyzed with SuSiE alone, indicating improved fine-mapping resolution.
title: Functionally-informed fine-mapping and polygenic localization of complex trait heritability

finding: The A allele of the rs1990760 polymorphism in the IFIH1 gene was associated with protection against arterial hypertension in type 1 diabetic patients and was linked to the expression of this gene in human mononuclear cells.
title: Identification of novel prognostic targets in coronary artery disease and related complications using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The analysis found that rs3827760 in the EDAR gene displayed a significant increase in allele frequency among populations with higher Eastern Eurasian affinity (such as Khovsgol_LBA and Ulaanzuuk_SlabGrave) during the analysis period, indicating it was a target of positive selection in those populations.
title: A dynamic 6,000-year genetic history of Eurasia’s Eastern Steppe

finding: The SNP rs1013940, resulting in the Ile89Val (I89V) substitution in the CHT, was initially associated with reduced choline transport in human studies. Specifically, it was shown that individuals heterozygous for the Val89 variant displayed attention deficits, heightened distractibility, and reduced frontal cortex activation during attention-demanding tasks. This variant had a minor allele frequency of 8-10% in Caucasians and exhibited reduced choline transport capacity (40-50% of wild type) in experimental models, without affecting the surface expression of the transporter. Further clinical studies linked the Val89 variant with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder and major depression, providing a strong context for its significance in cognitive function.
title: Disrupted choline clearance and sustained acetylcholine release in vivo by a common choline transporter coding variant associated with poor attentional control in humans

finding: The SNP rs1427407 was associated with BCL11A expression and beta-hemoglobin disorders. In the context of regulatory analysis, RELICS detected significant regulatory signals near this SNP, particularly in the h+62 region, which was previously reported to have signals of strong interest in relation to BCL11A.
title: Discovering functional sequences with RELICS, an analysis method for CRISPR regulatory screens

finding: The SNP rs2305133 demonstrated notable allelic effects on chromatin accessibility at chr2:113198521-11319959. It was recognized as the index SNP for a caPeak-HAQER overlap, indicating its relevance in gene expression modulation within the context of the study.
title: Wnt activity reveals context-specific genetic effects on gene regulation in neural progenitors

finding: The SNP rs979020 was associated with an increased expression of ANKRD44, which was linked to decreased risk of schizophrenia and a reduced volume of the left presubiculum body in the hippocampal subfield. This finding highlighted the connection between Wnt-responsive regulation of ANKRD44 in neural progenitors and schizophrenia-related traits.
title: Wnt activity reveals context-specific genetic effects on gene regulation in neural progenitors

finding: The SNP rs1992311 was identified as a CHIR-responsive caQTL, modulating expression of DPYSL5 and associated with the average thickness of the isthmus cingulate region. This linkage suggested the SNP could alter chromatin accessibility and impact neural development.
title: Wnt activity reveals context-specific genetic effects on gene regulation in neural progenitors

finding: The SNP rs4665363 was implicated as a putative causal variant potentially disrupting a Pou5f1::Sox2 motif. It was associated with downregulation of DPYSL5 expression, with potential implications for increasing the average thickness of the isthmus cingulate in the context of Wnt pathway stimulation.
title: Wnt activity reveals context-specific genetic effects on gene regulation in neural progenitors

finding: The polymorphism rs7570797 (p.Ser40Gly) in PROKR1 was linked to plateletcrit levels (p=1.59×10⁻⁷, β=-0.023, 95% CI: -0.032 to -0.015). This relationship was described as novel.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: The study identified associations of rs3749171 (p.Thr139Met) in GPR35 with monocyte count (p=7.5×10⁻¹⁷, β=-0.024, 95% CI: -0.031 to -0.019), adding to the understanding of variant associations to immune traits.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: An association was noted between rs4676410 and previously mentioned traits like ankylosing spondylitis and inflammatory bowel disease, confirming its involvement with immune responses.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: The polymorphism rs6437353 (p.Arg13His) was associated with mean platelet volume (p=2.8×10⁻⁹, β=-0.021, 95% CI: -0.028 to -0.014), presenting a novel finding.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: This variant was associated with monocyte count (p=2.6×10⁻⁸, β=0.013, 95% CI: 0.0084-0.017), highlighting immune system variations.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: Identified in the DNAse region of LINC00299, functioning alongside rs34580133, this SNP is involved in the regulation of a long non-coding RNA implicated in brain development, relevant to Alzheimer’s disease features.
title: GenEpi: Gene-based Epistasis Discovery Using Machine Learning

finding: This SNP, located with rs2052573 in a DNAse region, was shown to contribute to the expression control of LINC00299, associating it with potential roles in AD-related brain development.
title: GenEpi: Gene-based Epistasis Discovery Using Machine Learning

finding: This SNP was located in the eQTL of MICALCL, associated with AD, indicating a potential role in Alzheimer’s disease mechanisms.
title: GenEpi: Gene-based Epistasis Discovery Using Machine Learning

finding: Identified alongside rs11675339 in the context of neighboring gene expression control, indicating relevance to Alzheimer’s disease mechanisms.
title: GenEpi: Gene-based Epistasis Discovery Using Machine Learning

finding: The rs35744605 SNP, resulting in the E627X variant of the MDA5 protein, was associated with a loss-of-function phenotype. This variant was critical in understanding how genetic mutations in MDA5 contribute to intestinal inflammation in patients with IBD, particularly in response to enteric viromes from IBD colon tissue.
title: Human enteric viruses shape disease phenotype through divergent innate immunomodulation

finding: The rs35667974 SNP, leading to the I923V variant in the MDA5 gene, also demonstrated a loss-of-function phenotype. Both IBD-associated variants, including this one, exhibited impaired responses to poly(I:C) and RNA derived from healthy colon tissue, linking genetic variation in MDA5 with the severity of IBD.
title: Human enteric viruses shape disease phenotype through divergent innate immunomodulation

finding: The rs35732034 SNP, which introduces a splice donor site mutation at position +1 in intron 14, was shown to result in the skipping of exon 14 and a truncated protein product. This modification further impaired MDA5 function and reinforced the detrimental impact on barrier integrity in intestinal epithelial cells exposed to IBD-related viromes.
title: Human enteric viruses shape disease phenotype through divergent innate immunomodulation

finding: The variant rs13395911 exerted a regulatory effect on EFHD1 expression via FOXO1. In TT donors, this SNP increased FOXO1 binding, leading to higher EFHD1 expression levels, whereas in AA donors, FOXO1 binding was weak, correlating with lower EFHD1 expression. The findings established a link between the rs13395911 genotype and MASLD susceptibility through differential regulation of EFHD1.
title: Identification of genes conferring individual-level variation responsible for metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis using single-cell eQTL analysis

finding: The GCKR-related SNP rs780094, a proxy for rs11127048, was associated with 46 phenotypes in the UK Biobank, including metabolic traits like diabetes and hypercholesterolemia, illustrating its broad impact on metabolic pathways.
title: Genome-wide association study of plasma triglycerides, phospholipids and relation to cardio-metabolic risk factors

finding: rs34043159 was found to be associated with sporadic Alzheimer’s disease in southern Han Chinese. This indicates a potential role in the development of Alzheimer's disease, highlighting its relevance.
title: Bioinformatics analyses of significant genes, related pathways and candidate prognostic biomarkers in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs9712235 was identified as a significant lead variant in breast cancer risk, particularly after analysis in conjunction with a larger GWAS meta-analysis. This discovery contributed to the identification of the variant's association with the gene ETAA1.
title: Pleiotropy-guided transcriptome imputation from normal and tumor tissues identifies new candidate susceptibility genes for breast and ovarian cancer

finding: This SNP was associated with significant changes in the c-FLIP isoforms, notably reflecting increased use of a specific splice form.
title: Expression changes confirm genomic variants predicted to result in allele-specific, alternative mRNA splicing

finding: The SNP rs1865573 was associated with splicing quantitative trait loci (sQTL) for the gene GREB1, which is known to mediate estrogen and androgen regulation and has implications in endometriosis susceptibility. Significant differences in DNA methylation (DNAm) profiles in response to this SNP were observed between menstrual cycle phases and endometriosis stages.
title: Global Endometrial DNA Multi-omics Analysis Reveals Insights into mQTL Regulation and Associated Endometriosis Disease Risk

finding: The rs4988235 variant in the MCM6 gene was found to be associated with lactase-persistence in Eurasia. This SNP demonstrated a significant correlation with the ability of individuals to digest lactose beyond infancy, which was advantageous for early farmers relying on dairy products.
title: The mixed genetic origin of the first farmers of Europe

finding: The SNP rs906868 was demonstrated to have allele-specific regulation in luciferase reporter assays, which categorized it as a high-probability functional variant in relation to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
title: High-throughput identification of functional regulatory SNPs in systemic lupus erythematosus

finding: The study identified that patients with JAK2-V617F positive myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) had a nearly three-fold higher frequency of the homozygous AA genotype of rs16944 located in the promoter region of the IL1B gene compared to normal controls. Furthermore, MPN patients with the AA genotype demonstrated higher IL-1β serum levels than those with GG/GA or AA/AG genotypes, supporting the assertion that IL-1β promotes the expansion of the JAK2-mutant clone.
title: IL-1β promotes MPN disease initiation by favoring early clonal expansion of JAK2-mutant hematopoietic stem cells

finding: The analysis revealed that the homozygous GG genotype of rs1143627, located near the IL1B coding regions, was almost three times more prevalent in JAK2-V617F positive MPN patients compared to normal controls. Patients harboring this genotype exhibited elevated serum levels of IL-1β compared to those with GG/GA or AA/AG genotypes, indicating the role of this SNP in enhancing IL-1β production and favoring the clonal expansion associated with MPN.
title: IL-1β promotes MPN disease initiation by favoring early clonal expansion of JAK2-mutant hematopoietic stem cells

finding: Variant rs676210 was favoured by both MGflashfm and MGfm in fine-mapping signals from four lipids traits. It was also prioritised by the GLGC for HDL in EUR, AFR, and multi-group analysis, achieving a posterior probability (PP) of 0.957 in the UK Biobank.
title: Leveraging information between multiple population groups and traits improves fine-mapping resolution

finding: The 3' UTR variant rs57825321 was new to the prioritisation list for LDL and TC by both MGflashfm and MGfm, and it was polymorphic only in East Asian (EAS) populations.
title: Leveraging information between multiple population groups and traits improves fine-mapping resolution

finding: Upstream gene variant rs934197 was prioritised for LDL by both MGflashfm and MGfm, with MGfm providing a marginal posterior probability (mgMPP) of 0.348, which significantly increased to 0.944 in MGflashfm when leveraging information between traits for TC.
title: Leveraging information between multiple population groups and traits improves fine-mapping resolution

finding: Missense variant rs533617, which had a deleterious prediction by SIFT and showed a pooled MAF of 0.0281 across EUR, HIS, and South Asian (SAS) populations, was prioritised by both MGfm and MGflashfm. It demonstrated a PP of 1 for LDL and TC in prior analyses conducted on the UK Biobank.
title: Leveraging information between multiple population groups and traits improves fine-mapping resolution

finding: The SNP rs62158731 at the BIN1 locus was found to be associated with inferred disease stage in the Mayo Clinic cohort, showing a p-value of 4.68 x 10^-5. This association overlaps with known LOAD variants, suggesting its importance in disease progression.
title: Molecular estimation of neurodegeneration pseudotime in older brains

finding: As a proxy mediated by rs780094, this SNP was implicated in notable metabolic health associations and linked to several health-related phenotypes.
title: Genome-wide association study of plasma lipids

finding: The SNP rs3844582 showed an initial p-value of 3.54e-06 in the pilot GWAS, suggesting a potential association with suicide attempts. Although it showed a marginal association in the replication study (p-value = 5.79e-02), this association did not withstand correction for multiple testing but had the lowest combined p-value (p = 5.09e-05) across studies.
title: Genome-wide copy number variation-, validation- and screening study implicates a novel copy number polymorphism associated with suicide attempts in major depressive disorder

finding: SNP rs76338508 was associated with greater CT in ADHD, reflecting its genetic impact on cortical architecture.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs6543224 showed a significant correlation with increased thickness in the inferior temporal cortex for autism spectrum disorder (ASD), emphasizing its contribution.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs10188273 was linked to lower SA of the perirhinal cortex for ASD, highlighting its impact on brain morphology.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs3769484 exhibited associations with lower SA and CT in the primary cortex for both BD and SCZ, demonstrating its genetic relevance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs295140 was implicated in reduced SA and CT in shared primary regions for both BD and SCZ, underlining its impact.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs2445956 exhibited opposite effect directions for surface area in ASD and PTSD, showing a complex relationship that suggests divergent neurogenetic pathways.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs11123965 was associated with opposite effect directions on surface area in ASD and PTSD, reinforcing the idea of distinct genetic mechanisms across these disorders.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs264975 indicated differing effect directions for cortical measures in ASD versus PTSD, highlighting the complexity of genetic influences in psychiatric conditions.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs2198234 was shown to have contrasting effects on cortical structure across ASD and PTSD, illustrating the variability in genetic pathways.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs1673468 exhibited conflicting effects on cortical surface area in the analysis of ASD and PTSD, pointing to distinct genetic associations.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs264963 showed opposite effect directions on cortical measurements in ASD and PTSD, suggestive of divergent genetic underpinnings.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs2084814 indicated varying directions of effect on structural measures in ASD and PTSD, highlighting the complexity of associated genetic factors.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs1869073 had differing associations across autism and PTSD regarding surface area, supporting the hypothesis of distinct genetic pathways.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs2084200 was linked to decreased cortical thickness in lateral prefrontal cortex for ASD, revealing its genetic significance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure
