finding: The SNP rs13030468 was identified as a significant marker related to the development of high-grade serous carcinoma (HGSC). It was associated with the transformation activity attributed to the sustained presence of hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) derived from the ovulatory follicular fluid (FF). This sustained activity was linked to the long-term effects of FF on the fallopian tube fimbrial epithelium and its role in facilitating malignant transformation leading to HGSC.
title: Ovulation sources coagulation protease cascade and hepatocyte growth factor to support physiological growth and malignant transformation

finding: The SNP rs13030373 was explored in relation to the modulation of CD4 T cell responses in the tumor cytokine microenvironment as presented by Accogli et al. in 2021. This research illustrated how variations at this SNP could impact immune responses within the TME, affecting therapeutic outcomes.
title: From tumor microenvironment to immuno-therapeutic outcomes for solid tumors: A systems theoretic approach

finding: The SNP rs13020197 was associated with increased relative expression levels of Bcl-2, which played a crucial role in enhancing the persistence of chimeric antigen receptor T cells in cancer treatments, thereby influencing the survival of monocytes (MOs) during T-ALL.
title: Combination therapy of metformin with sodium selenite reverses effects of monotherapy on nitric oxide production, IL-1β and TNF-α release, and upregulates relative expression of Bcl-2 by LPS-activated human primary monocytes in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia

finding: The SNP rs11498 located in the IBD-associated Immunochip region 2p15 was found to influence m6A methylation levels on the lncRNA LOC339803. This differential methylation affected YTHDC1 protein binding affinity, subsequently regulating expression levels of the proinflammatory cytokine IL1B. In individuals with the G allele conferring risk for intestinal inflammation, the m6A methylation of LOC339803 was determined to be higher, leading to increased expression of IL1B and contributing to chronic inflammation. This SNP's association with IBD underscores the role of LOC339803 as a key player in the inflammatory processes underlying this disease.
title: m6A methylated long noncoding RNA regulates proinflammatory response emerging as novel target for IBD

finding: SNP rs55927047 was located in the FOXN2 promoter and significantly enhanced TEAD1's ability to bind to this region, which activated FOXN2 expression in myelinating Schwann cells (mSCs). This finding was supported by overlapping orthologous rat PNS TEAD1 ChIP-seq peaks and indicated a link to inflammatory polyneuropathy due to FOXN2 being identified as a risk gene for this condition.
title: NetREm: Network Regression Embeddings reveal cell-type transcription factor coordination for gene regulation

finding: SNP rs79073127 was identified as correlating positively with increased FOXN2 expression and associated with a higher risk of inflammatory polyneuropathy based on GWAS involving the Pan UK Biobank. It demonstrated a significant linkage disequilibrium with rs55927047.
title: NetREm: Network Regression Embeddings reveal cell-type transcription factor coordination for gene regulation

finding: The C to T mutation at rs4988235 was confirmed as the primary determinant for lactase persistence (LP) in both European and South Asian populations. It was identified that this mutation arose in the Pontic Steppe between 23,000 and 5,960 years ago, then emigrated into Europe and South Asia during the Bronze Age via the Steppe ancestry expansion. The association of this SNP with LP was noted to be perfect in both Finnish and non-Finnish samples, emphasizing its significance in the trait.
title: Population genomics on the origin of lactase persistence in Europe and South Asia

finding: The G to A mutation at rs182549 was determined to have arisen earlier than 23,000 years ago. It was highlighted that this SNP is closely associated with lactase persistence alongside rs4988235, with a nearly perfect association observed in case-control studies. The A allele of this SNP was shown to enhance the LCT promoter activity, although to a lesser extent than the T allele at rs4988235.
title: Population genomics on the origin of lactase persistence in Europe and South Asia

finding: The SNP rs1260326 was associated with Apolipoprotein A1 (APOA1), which is a known risk factor for Alzheimer's disease. The removal of this SNP during analysis increased the strength of the observed protective effect of circulating glutamine on Alzheimer's disease, with an odds ratio of 0.81 (95% CI 0.69, 0.96; P = 0.01). This indicated that adjusting for the pleiotropic effect of rs1260326 provided clearer evidence of the protective role of glutamine in preventing cognitive decline.
title: Circulating glutamine and Alzheimer’s disease: a Mendelian randomization study

finding: The SNP rs13030369 was associated with the gene AKT1, identified as a prevalent candidate gene linked directly to neurological phenotypes within the context of COVID-19. This finding suggested a direct impact of the AKT signaling pathway, which is crucial in neurogenesis and neurodegenerative processes. The analysis highlighted the significant role of AKT1 in mediating both cellular signaling and neurodevelopmental diseases, relating it to the underlying neurological symptoms observed in COVID-19 patients.
title: Candidate genes associated with neurological manifestations of COVID-19: Meta-analysis using multiple computational approaches

finding: This SNP was associated with several autoimmune disorders, including type I diabetes mellitus (T1DM), vitiligo, and psoriasis. It was also linked to an increased interferon signaling signature in the tumor, suggesting a positive correlation with immune response to cancer.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: Similar to rs2111485, this SNP was associated with autoimmune diseases like T1DM and lupus. Its association with increased interferon signaling suggests it influences immune response in tumors.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: This SNP was noted for its association with psoriasis, suggesting its involvement in autoimmune conditions related to the interferon response.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: This SNP was strongly associated with CD8 T-cell LSES, demonstrating robust influence in immune traits.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: The variant rs10171498 was associated with the gain of a NFIX footprint. This finding was supported by allelic imbalance assessments that utilized DNase I cleavage data from 56 heterozygous samples, as well as homozygous samples that revealed differential cleavage patterns. The precise colocalization of the variant and the differentially footprinted nucleotides with a NFIX recognition element was highlighted as a significant finding, indicating an impact on transcription factor occupancy and regulatory function. Furthermore, the density of imbalanced variants within a footprinted NFIX recognition sequence was analyzed, reinforcing the role of genetic variation in influencing gene regulatory mechanisms.
title: Global reference mapping and dynamics of human transcription factor footprints

finding: The SNP rs13389219 was identified as having the lowest interaction P-value of 2.6×10^-71 in a gene-gender interaction analysis related to waist-hip ratio, indicating a substantial effect of this variant on the trait, particularly in the context of gender.
title: Scalable and flexible gene-environment interaction analysis in millions of samples

finding: The investigation related to SNP rs2041838 provided a finding that was linked to the NF-kB signaling pathway in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL). It was noted that the NF-kB pathway played oncogenic roles in both leukemic and microenvironmental cells, contributing to the chemotherapy resistance and the stem-like properties of certain T-ALL cell populations. This context was crucial as it helped establish a mechanistic understanding of how specific genetic variants might influence resistance to treatment.
title: Role of Stem-Like Cells in Chemotherapy Resistance and Relapse in pediatric T Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia

finding: The SNP rs893403 was associated with death censored graft loss (DCGL) in kidney transplant recipients, particularly when the donor introduced the A allele into recipients carrying the homozygous G allele. This finding confirmed previous reports indicating a risk mismatch associated with rejection episodes in multiple cohorts.
title: Multiscale genetic architecture of donor-recipient differences reveals intronic LIMS1 locus mismatches associated with long-term renal transplant survival

finding: SNP rs2460944 was found to be in high linkage disequilibrium with rs893403 and associated with death censored graft loss (DCGL) in a manner similar to rs893403. The association indicated that this polymorphism, located within the regulatory region, might also function as a regulatory element modulating GCC2 expression.
title: Multiscale genetic architecture of donor-recipient differences reveals intronic LIMS1 locus mismatches associated with long-term renal transplant survival

finding: The SNP rs10084199 was reported to be associated with DCGL and was found within accessible chromatin regions in the LIMS1 locus. Like other SNPs analyzed, it demonstrated significant eQTL function for the GCC2 gene, playing a potential role in graft survival.
title: Multiscale genetic architecture of donor-recipient differences reveals intronic LIMS1 locus mismatches associated with long-term renal transplant survival

finding: SNP rs4012003 was included in the identified haplotypes of LIMS1 and showed significant associations with DCGL. This SNP was part of the intronic region, linking it to the modulation of GCC2 and TGF-beta signaling pathways, crucial for transplant outcomes.
title: Multiscale genetic architecture of donor-recipient differences reveals intronic LIMS1 locus mismatches associated with long-term renal transplant survival

finding: SNP rs12622759, located in an area of open chromatin, was identified among those associated with DCGL. This SNP likely contributes to the regulatory dynamics influencing GCC2 expression and thereby affecting allograft outcomes.
title: Multiscale genetic architecture of donor-recipient differences reveals intronic LIMS1 locus mismatches associated with long-term renal transplant survival

finding: The cfQTL effect of rs1176895555 on the expression of GOLGABL1 was significantly correlated in neutrophils, with a Spearman correlation coefficient of 0.92 (p-value = 0.001). This finding illustrated a strong cellular interaction concerning immune response in the tumor microenvironment.
title: A novel method to identify cell-type specific regulatory variants and their role in cancer risk

finding: The study reported that at locus which had rs78198962 as the lead SNP, the Finemap-MiXeR method identified 24 SNPs that were predictive of the phenotype related to standing height. In comparison, other methods like SuSiE and FINEMAP only detected 7 SNPs at this locus. This difference contributed to the Finemap-MiXeR's capability of achieving a significantly higher R2 value, thus demonstrating its effectiveness in finemapping genetic data.
title: Finemap-MiXeR: A variational Bayesian approach for genetic finemapping

finding: The SNP rs10933431, located in intron 2 of the INPP5D gene (which encodes SHIP1), was associated with increased expression of SHIP1 and was linked to an increased risk of late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) specifically in Caucasians.
title: Regulation of inositol 5-phosphatase activity by the C2 domain of SHIP1 and SHIP2

finding: The SNP rs35349669, found in intron 10 of the INPP5D gene (SHIP1), was also associated with increased expression of SHIP1 and contributed to an increased risk of late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) in Caucasians; however, this specific mutation did not correlate with a similar increased risk in the Han Chinese population.
title: Regulation of inositol 5-phosphatase activity by the C2 domain of SHIP1 and SHIP2

finding: The low-frequency intronic variant rs988583 in the PLCL1 gene was significantly associated with prevalent myocardial infarction (MI), with an odds ratio of 1.80 and a p-value of 7.12 x 10^-7, indicating an increased risk.
title: Genetic loci associated with prevalent and incident myocardial infarction and coronary heart disease in the Cohorts for Heart and Aging Research in Genomic Epidemiology (CHARGE) Consortium

finding: The variant rs6733839-T was discovered in the BIN1 locus and acted as a stimulation-dependent eQTL variant residing in a PU.1 binding site. It disrupted the binding motif of the MEF2 transcription factor and was linked to BIN1 expression in monocytes stimulated with IFN-γ, indicating its role in AD risk.
title: Integration of Alzheimer’s disease genetics and myeloid cell genomics identifies novel causal variants, regulatory elements, genes and pathways

finding: In the BIN1 locus, the variant rs13025717-T was also found in a PU.1 binding site and was confirmed as a binding QTL for PU.1 in a B-lymphoblastoid cell line. This SNP acted as an eQTL for BIN1 and was associated with AD risk by affecting PU.1 binding through disruption of motifs for its binding partners.
title: Integration of Alzheimer’s disease genetics and myeloid cell genomics identifies novel causal variants, regulatory elements, genes and pathways

finding: The SNP rs1519102 was identified as a putative causal variant in strong linkage disequilibrium with the MEIS1 locus, which is one of the strongest association signals from previous insomnia GWAS. Mutation of its ortholog, meis1b, in zebrafish resulted in significantly fragmented nighttime sleep and increased sleep latency, aligning with insomnia-like behaviors.
title: Zebrafish screen of high-confidence effector genes at insomnia GWAS loci implicates conserved regulators of sleep-wake behaviors

finding: The SNP rs13010068 was linked to the application of thermal imaging for detecting plant stress and phenotyping. This finding emphasized the role of certain genetic markers in improving the robustness of machine learning models designed for identifying stressed plants, highlighting their potential utility in advanced stress detection methodologies in vertical farming systems.
title: Infrared thermography for plant stress detection in vertical farms: Investigating spatiotemporal variations and exploring solutions via machine learning

finding: The rs2304672 SNP in the PER2 gene was identified as moderating the activity of circadian-relevant reward circuitry in adolescents. This finding highlights the role of circadian genes in the modulation of reward processing and potentially addiction outcomes.
title: Circadian- and sex-dependent increases in intravenous cocaine self-administration in Npas2 mutant mice

finding: The SNP rs115015150 was identified as being significantly associated with preeclampsia (PE) and several quantitative cardiovascular risk traits. This finding was based on prior population studies that proposed Rnd3 as a candidate gene for PE. The downregulation of Rnd3 was found to correlate with mitochondrial dysfunction and increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) in placental trophoblast cells from PE patients, reinforcing the role of Rnd3 in PE pathogenesis.
title: RND3/RhoE deficiency in preeclamptic women impairs placental mitochondrial function via regulation of the PPARgamma-UCP2 pathway

finding: The SNP rs2009094 was identified as significantly associated with RBC, correlating with trait values in both mammals and CC mice, suggesting its involvement in red blood cell phenotypes.
title: Parallel evolution at the regulatory base-pair level contributes to mammalian inter-specific differences in polygenic traits

finding: The variant rs2382817 (A/C) was mapped as puQTL influencing two active promoters of the TMBIM1 gene (p = 3.50 x 10^-68, beta = 1.03 for prmtr.64998; p = 1.71 x 10^-9, beta = 0.41 for prmtr.65000). It was also associated with the total expression level of TMBIM1 (p = 1.62 x 10^-41, beta = 0.85), and its alternative allele was linked with a decrease in IBD risk, suggesting a functional role in the disease context.
title: Mapping of promoter usage QTL using RNA-seq data reveals their contributions to complex traits

finding: The SNP rs754834233 caused a proline to leucine mutation (P318L) in the Bin1 protein, which was identified as being associated with late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD). The mutation led to a reduced interaction with BACE1, resulting in a loss of function related to endocytic recycling, which was linked to increased intracellular beta-amyloid accumulation (iAbeta) and early endosome enlargement.
title: Alzheimer’s disease BIN1 coding variants increase intracellular Aβ by interfering with BACE1 recycling

finding: The SNP rs138047593 caused an arginine to lysine mutation (K358R) in the Bin1 protein, contributing to the risk of late-onset Alzheimer's disease. Similar to rs754834233, this mutation resulted in decreased interaction with BACE1, thereby promoting defective endocytic recycling and an increase in intracellular Aβ42 accumulation.
title: Alzheimer’s disease BIN1 coding variants increase intracellular Aβ by interfering with BACE1 recycling

finding: The SNP rs7420166 was located within the gene BOK and showed a significant association with PT asymmetry, with an unadjusted P value of 7.54x10^-10. This SNP was involved in expression affecting both BOK and another gene DTYMK, and resulted in increased leftward asymmetry. Additionally, it was nominally associated with educational attainment through proxy SNPs, displaying minor allele A's influence on brain asymmetry.
title: Genetic effects on planum temporale asymmetry and their limited relevance to neurodevelopmental disorders, intelligence or educational attainment

finding: The SNP rs4246610 was associated with waist-hip ratio (WHR) through a gene-sex interaction analysis conducted on 352,768 individuals from the UK Biobank. It was identified as part of a joint test yielding a p-value of 2.6×10^-8. Notably, this locus had not previously been reported in the BMI-adjusted WHR GWAS from the GIANT Consortium, indicating it was a novel finding within the study.
title: GEM: Scalable and flexible gene-environment interaction analysis in millions of samples

finding: The SNP rs7570971 at the LCT locus was identified as a genome-wide significant signal of selection in the UK, with a p-value of 8.51 × 10-16. It was included among previously reported signals of selection.
title: Scalable probabilistic PCA for large-scale genetic variation data

finding: The rs11887534 variant, identified as a missense mutation within the ABCG8 gene, replicated in the MEGASTROKE stroke GWAS with a p-value significance of 6.85E-04. This discovery points to the gene's involvement in aspects related to stroke, specifically concerning lipid metabolism and inflammation.
title: Medical data and machine learning improve power of stroke genome-wide association studies

finding: SNP rs2124440 was associated with increased measurement of nucleic acid content in monocytes. It displayed colocalization with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) associations and is thought to indicate that monocytes may mediate some effects and mechanisms targeted by the antibody therapy Vedolizumab in treating IBD.
title: Genetic Analyses of Blood Cell Structure for Biological and Pharmacological Inference

finding: This SNP was linked to Alzheimer's disease and identified as a significant eQTL for the BIN1 gene in aorta, and moderately in brain cerebellum, showcasing its association with the disease despite the aorta not being the primary relevant tissue.
title: Genome-Wide Large-Scale Multi-Trait Analysis Characterizes Global Patterns of Pleiotropy and Unique Trait-Specific Variants

finding: The SNP rs6756629 was linked to the ABCG5 gene, which is associated with total cholesterol and LDL levels. It was noted that this missense mutation appeared at high frequency in the HUI population and was related to increased cholesterol levels, which represent a risk factor for coronary heart disease.
title: Population history and gene divergence in Native Mexicans inferred from 76 human exomes

finding: The SNP rs13652 was associated with type 2 diabetes and was responsible for a missense mutation resulting in an amino acid change (1575Asp to E(Glu) to D(Asp)). The findings indicated a significant correlation with fasting glucose-related parameters, reinforcing the role of this SNP in diabetes pathology.
title: Single-Cell RNA-seq of Heart Reveals Intercellular Communication Drivers of Myocardial Fibrosis in Diabetic Mice

finding: The alternative allele rs114518452-C was experimentally verified as an off-target site associated with gene editing using CRISPR technology. The study included a heterozygous donor for this SNP during the assessment of off-target effects of sgRNAs, revealing the influence of this genetic variant on editing specificity.
title: Scalable assessment of genome editing off-targets associated with genetic variants

finding: The SNP rs6742078 was strongly associated with disorders of bilirubin metabolism, specifically linked to Gilbert’s syndrome. It was noted for its significant signal within the UGT1A10 gene and was previously identified in multiple SNP GWAS studies. This SNP was also related to other lipid metabolism disorders such as Gallstones Disease (GSD), although CNV burden analysis in lipid metabolism genes showed enrichment in GSD cases without attributing the associations to any single gene.
title: CNest: A Novel Copy Number Association Discovery Method Uncovers 862 New Associations from 200,629 Whole Exome Sequence Datasets in the UK Biobank

finding: The missense variant rs1260326 in GCKR colocalised with 49 metabolites and indicated potential causal effects on glucose metabolism.
title: Cross-platform genetic discovery of small molecule products of metabolism and application to clinical outcomes

finding: At the CERS6 locus, rs4143279 was linked with sphingomyelin levels, marking a novel association with this metabolite.
title: Cross-platform genetic discovery of small molecule products of metabolism and application to clinical outcomes

finding: The SNP rs2553628 was notably associated with PACG as it was demonstrated to influence enhancer activity through dual luciferase reporter assays, showing significantly higher luciferase activity for the G allele compared to the A allele (P value = 0.0034). This was significant as it indicated a direct functional role in the context of glaucomatous neurodegeneration.
title: Post-GWAS functional analyses of CNTNAP5 suggests its role in glaucomatous neurodegeneration

finding: The SNP rs17011429, strong with rs2553628 in linkage disequilibrium, was indicated as having high gene regulatory potential and was associated with co-eQTL roles in schizophrenia, hinting at its potential involvement in neurodegenerative processes.
title: Post-GWAS functional analyses of CNTNAP5 suggests its role in glaucomatous neurodegeneration

finding: SNP rs5835988 was linked to both COBLL1 and GRB14 and was shown to have significant interactive effects in obesity-related traits.
title: Identifying latent genetic interactions in genome-wide association studies using multiple traits

finding: The SNP rs140256046, associated with the gene Mogat1, was found to be a significant eQTL (expression quantitative trait locus) in human subcutaneous adipose tissue with a p-value of 1.5e-5. This finding illustrates the relevance of the gene in metabolic processes, especially related to adiposity traits, as evidenced in both mouse models and human tissue.
title: Epistatic Networks Associated with Parent-of-Origin Effects on Metabolic Traits

finding: The association between rs12466331 and CALM2 was significant in excitatory neurons but not in bulk-tissue data. CALM2 encodes calmodulin, which is highly expressed in excitatory neurons and has been found downregulated in the postmortem brains of schizophrenia (SCZ) patients. These findings suggested that rs12466331 may regulate CALM2 expression in excitatory neurons, indicating that dysregulation of this pathway might be linked to SCZ.
title: Evaluating performance and applications of sample-wise cell deconvolution methods on human brain transcriptomic data

finding: rs144040771 was colocalized with the SCZ GWAS risk locus rs12466331. This colocalization suggested a potential connection between the two SNPs and their respective associations with schizophrenia risk, facilitating the understanding of molecular mechanisms underlying the disease.
title: Evaluating performance and applications of sample-wise cell deconvolution methods on human brain transcriptomic data

finding: The SNP rs231779 was identified as a fine-mapped SNP (PIP=0.91) for 'All Auto Immune Traits' and linked by the ABC S2G strategy to the gene CTLA4. CTLA4, ranked 109 based on the PPI-enhancer gene score, is recognized as an immune checkpoint regulator with significant implications in cancer immunotherapy.
title: SNP-to-gene linking strategies reveal contributions of enhancer-related and candidate master-regulator genes to autoimmune disease

finding: It was identified as a potential outlier for total breast cancer risk but showed no significant associations in analyses regarding coffee consumption.
title: Coffee consumption and risk of breast cancer: a Mendelian Randomization study

finding: Associated with the KEAP1-NRF2 system, rs13010046 was found to be relevant as a molecular target in cancer treatment. The activation of the Nrf2 pathway by cigarette smoke exposure was identified as a critical mechanism influencing HNSCC aggressiveness, with implications for improving response to treatment.
title: Tobacco smoke exposure is a driver of altered oxidative stress response and immunity in head and neck cancer

finding: The SNP rs11688767 had a p-value of 3.2×10−4 in the meta-analysis of rMDD, constituting a significant original finding.
title: Sex-Dependent Shared and Non-Shared Genetic Architecture Across Mood and Psychotic Disorders

finding: The rs744373 SNP was reported as associated with increased tau accumulation, which speculatively related to faster atrophy rates in the medial temporal lobe structures of healthy adults, influenced by AD risk variants. This SNP was specifically linked to the brain's vulnerability to structural loss observed across aging and Alzheimer's disease, implying that carriers of this SNP might experience accelerated neurodegeneration in relation to memory decline.
title: Accelerated brain change in healthy adults is associated with genetic risk for Alzheimer’s disease and uncovers adult lifespan memory decline

finding: This SNP was identified as overlapping with a distal enhancer linked to CTLA4, which plays a crucial role in regulating T cell responses. The enhancer also affected ICOS and CD28 expressions, which are more distal genes. These findings related to dysregulated T cell signaling can contribute to the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases.
title: Integration of genetic and epigenetic data pinpoints autoimmune specific remodelling of enhancer landscape in CD4+ T cells

finding: Like rs56324422, this SNP was part of a distal enhancer affecting CTLA4, ICOS, and CD28. The implications of this include insights into the regulatory mechanisms involved in T cell activation and the potential for autoimmune disease development.
title: Integration of genetic and epigenetic data pinpoints autoimmune specific remodelling of enhancer landscape in CD4+ T cells

finding: This SNP was associated with the distal enhancer affecting CTLA4, as well as ICOS and CD28, suggesting its role in the regulatory landscapes that contribute to the immune responses involved in autoimmune disorders.
title: Integration of genetic and epigenetic data pinpoints autoimmune specific remodelling of enhancer landscape in CD4+ T cells

finding: Similar to the other SNPs, this SNP was found within the enhancer that regulates CTLA4, ICOS, and CD28. Its presence indicates a potential link to mechanisms of T cell dysregulation associated with autoimmune diseases.
title: Integration of genetic and epigenetic data pinpoints autoimmune specific remodelling of enhancer landscape in CD4+ T cells

finding: Found in the same enhancer context as the other SNPs, this SNP also contributed to the regulation of CTLA4, ICOS, and CD28. The dysregulation of these signals is relevant to autoimmune disease pathogenesis.
title: Integration of genetic and epigenetic data pinpoints autoimmune specific remodelling of enhancer landscape in CD4+ T cells

finding: This SNP was part of the enhancer linked to CTLA4 along with ICOS and CD28, associating it with T cell response dysregulation in autoimmune diseases.
title: Integration of genetic and epigenetic data pinpoints autoimmune specific remodelling of enhancer landscape in CD4+ T cells

finding: The variant rs13025717 at the BIN1 locus was confirmed as a causal variant with MPRA showing p = 2.4 × 10−41 and CRISPR experiments in microglia yielding p = 1.3 × 10−5, confirming its critical role in Alzheimer's disease.
title: Beyond guilty by association at scale: searching for causal variants on the basis of genome-wide summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs4988235 was identified to exhibit positive selection in the UK population. This SNP was shown to regulate the lactase gene (LCT) expression, corroborating previous studies. Additionally, tests for selection around the LCT locus were determined to be the most significant among all variants on chromosome 2.
title: diplo-locus: A lightweight toolkit for inference and simulation of time-series genetic data under general diploid selection

finding: The rs17481869 locus was identified as a susceptibility locus associated with ETV6-RUNX1 patients, and it was located within an open chromatin region specific to pro-B cells, indicating its potential role in mechanisms of malignant transformation.
title: Uncovering the cis-regulatory program of early human B-cell commitment and its implications in the pathogenesis of B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia

finding: The SNP rs13030399 was implicated in advancing spring phenology due to artificial light at night in the United States, as noted by Zheng, Teo, and Koh in 2021. This discovery illustrated how urbanization and light pollution could disrupt natural synchrony in ecological patterns, emphasizing its ecological relevance.
title: Ecological synchrony in human-modified landscapes under a changing climate

finding: The rs72844419 variant at the GGCX locus was identified in macrophages, highlighting its link to CAD risk.
title: Cell-specific chromatin landscape of human coronary artery resolves regulatory mechanisms of disease risk

finding: SNP rs62183161 associated with the phylum Actinobacteria, notably linked to body composition measures and energy intake, thus establishing genetic influences on specific gut microbial taxa.
title: M-GWAS for the gut microbiome in Chinese adults illuminates on complex diseases

finding: SNP rs1453123 at OXR1 demonstrated a significant association with the family Prevotellaceae (P = 1.58 × 10−8) and replicated in the validation cohort with P = 0.006, indicating its role in maintaining microbiome diversity.
title: M-GWAS for the gut microbiome in Chinese adults illuminates on complex diseases

finding: The missense variant rs3749147 in GPN1 was linked with Eggerthella abundance with a significance level of P = 3.2 × 10−8, further establishing genetic associations with gut microbiome taxa.
title: M-GWAS for the gut microbiome in Chinese adults illuminates on complex diseases

finding: SNP rs13420238 at LOC150935 had a significant association with Bifidobacterium longum, with a P value of 0.007, reflecting its relationship with gut microbiota diversity.
title: M-GWAS for the gut microbiome in Chinese adults illuminates on complex diseases

finding: SNP rs72627489 near SOWAHC was found associated with Alistipes shahii, which has implications for gut microbiome diversity and health outcomes.
title: M-GWAS for the gut microbiome in Chinese adults illuminates on complex diseases

finding: This SNP was noted as a highly suggestive locus for MUC5AC, indicating a potential influence on mucin concentrations. Its implications for COPD phenotypes were not specified in the text.
title: Genetic Regulators of Sputum Mucin Concentration and Their Associations with COPD Phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs2044469 was associated with the expression level of the SLC25A12 gene, which was relevant to grip strength (GS). Alterations in SLC25A12 expression were found to affect mitochondrial structure and function, linking it to age-related muscle dysfunction.
title: Shared regulatory pathways reveal novel genetic correlations between grip strength and neuromuscular disorders

finding: The SNP rs4953911 was associated with the expression level of the SLC25A12 gene, contributing to the regulation of gene expression in multiple sclerosis (MS). Changes in this gene's expression affected mitochondrial function and were linked to muscle weakness.
title: Shared regulatory pathways reveal novel genetic correlations between grip strength and neuromuscular disorders

finding: The SNP rs882300 was also associated with the SLC25A12 gene expression linked to MS. This gene's altered expression due to rs882300 was noted to have impacts on mitochondrial functionality, influencing muscle health.
title: Shared regulatory pathways reveal novel genetic correlations between grip strength and neuromuscular disorders

finding: The SNP rs1400816 showed a correlation with ALS and affected the expression of SLC25A12. The findings indicated that expression changes could relate to muscle weakness due to age and neuromuscular diseases.
title: Shared regulatory pathways reveal novel genetic correlations between grip strength and neuromuscular disorders

finding: The rs139297920 variant in the PAX3 gene was identified as a potential misannotation, being incorrectly labeled as a donor splice site variant. It actually falls within the 3'-UTR of the most expressed and conserved isoform of PAX3 (ENST00000350526), and this variant was associated with an exon showing the lowest CCR percentile with no ClinVar variant reports.
title: Harnessing population-specific protein truncating variants to improve the annotation of loss-of-function alleles

finding: The SNP rs9677504 was significantly associated with ADHD and OCD with a p-value of 8.04 x 10^-10; both disorders exhibited high m-values (m_ADHD = 1, m_OCD = 0.995), suggesting strong evidence for a shared genetic effect.
title: Cross-disorder GWAS meta-analysis for Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, Autism Spectrum Disorder, Obsessive Compulsive Disorder, and Tourette Syndrome

finding: Variant rs6752964 was predicted to mediate associations with THADA and THADA-AS, where its genetic influences suggested a higher likelihood of abdominal obesity yet protection from type 2 diabetes. The investigation indicated that THADA might play a role in intracellular calcium signaling related to these phenotypes.
title: Predicting mechanisms of action at genetic loci associated with discordant effects on type 2 diabetes and abdominal fat accumulation

finding: The SNP rs7570682 on chromosome 2 was associated with bipolar disorder and had been independently validated in later studies, confirming its relevance within the context of psychiatric genetic research.
title: DeepCOMBI: Explainable artificial intelligence for the analysis and discovery in genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs1375144, located on chromosome 2, was also linked to bipolar disorder and had undergone independent validation in subsequent studies, solidifying its role in the genetics of this condition.
title: DeepCOMBI: Explainable artificial intelligence for the analysis and discovery in genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs231726 on chromosome 2 was found to be associated with type 1 diabetes and had been validated by other independent studies, reinforcing its role in the genetic understanding of this autoimmune condition.
title: DeepCOMBI: Explainable artificial intelligence for the analysis and discovery in genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs6718526 on chromosome 2 was associated with type 2 diabetes and validated through subsequent research, underscoring its importance in the genetic landscape of metabolic disorders.
title: DeepCOMBI: Explainable artificial intelligence for the analysis and discovery in genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs13020230 was associated with BCAT1 expression levels in glioblastoma. Low expression of BCAT1 correlated with differentiated glioblastoma subtypes, as indicated by knockout studies showing a differentiation in phenotype. This finding highlighted the potential role of this SNP in influencing glioblastoma cell behavior and immune response, ultimately contributing to tumor growth suppression.
title: BCAT1 regulates glioblastoma cell plasticity and contributes to immunosuppression

finding: The SNP rs80006029, corresponding to the Rabl2 L119F variant, was identified as a deleterious variant that destabilized the RABL2A protein. When modeled in mice, this mutation resulted in disorders associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) and Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS), notably causing male infertility, excessive weight, growth retardation, heterotaxia, pre-axial polydactyly, neural tube defects (NTD), and hydrocephalus.
title: Variants in RABL2A causing male infertility and ciliopathy

finding: The SNP rs200121688, which denotes the Rabl2 V158F variant, was determined to be a functionally deleterious allele that compromised protein stability. Mice bearing this variant displayed PCD and BBS-related phenotypes, including male infertility, excessive weight gain, developmental delays, heterotaxia, pre-axial polydactyly, NTD, and hydrocephalus.
title: Variants in RABL2A causing male infertility and ciliopathy

finding: The mutation rs10153620 was associated with the target gene NRP2, as identified by the TransEPI model with a high prediction score of 0.9100. The identification of this target gene was supported by Hi-C data, confirming its relevance in neural functions and diseases.
title: Capturing large genomic contexts for accurately predicting enhancer-promoter interactions

finding: The SNP rs13020183 was identified as having a significant association with the CMS4 subtype of colorectal cancer (CRC), which is characterized by a high occurrence of hepatic metastasis. The investigation revealed that TGFbeta signaling influences the abundance of cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) that are involved in the microenvironment of CRC tumors. The presence of specific IL-6 cytokine family members, including IL-6 and IL-11, induced by TGFbeta isoforms was crucial in promoting a neutrophil-dependent hepatic niche, thereby enhancing the metastatic potential of CRC tumors classified under CMS4.
title: TGFβ signaling in cancer-associated fibroblasts drives a hepatic gp130-dependent pro-metastatic inflammatory program in CMS4 colorectal cancer subtype

finding: The SNP rs28445040, associated with Crohn's disease, was linked to structural perturbations of the SP140 protein caused by the splicing of exon 13. This finding replicated prior results from Zhao et al. Using different datasets, it was shown that alternative splicing of exon 13 did not significantly affect the protein core, as it was located within an intrinsically disordered region.
title: The impact of genetically controlled splicing on exon inclusion and protein structure

finding: The STAT4 rs11889341(T) risk allele was implicated in heightened risk for myocardial infarction and nephritis, particularly in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, showcasing its relevance in autoimmunity and cardiovascular health.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The low allele frequency of SNP rs1990760 in IFIH1 was linked to less IFN-beta expression and potential vulnerability to COVID-19 infection, marking it as a key player in immune response to viral infections.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The rs55703767 SNP in COL4A3, MMP-9 and TIMP-1 gene polymorphisms was associated with susceptibility to type 2 diabetes, contributing to the genetic landscape of metabolic disorders.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The STAT4 gene variant rs7574865 was assessed for its association with type 1 diabetes mellitus, reinforcing the genetic connection in autoimmune conditions.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs13025717 was recognized for its role in repressing the microglia CRE for the gene BIN1, establishing its relevance in Alzheimer's disease risk through modulation of gene expression.
title: Deconvolution of polygenic risk score in single cells unravels cellular and molecular heterogeneity of complex human diseases

finding: The SNP IL1B C-511T (rs16944) was found to be associated with impaired cognition and increased risk for alcohol drinking and alcohol use disorder (AUD). In vitro analyses from human studies indicated that this SNP potentiated both IL-1β gene expression and release, suggesting a significant role of the IL-1 system in cognitive symptoms linked to AUD and related neuropsychiatric conditions such as bipolar disorder, major depressive disorder, and schizophrenia.
title: Ethanol drinking sex-dependently alters cortical IL-1β synaptic signaling and cognitive behavior in mice

finding: The SNP rs1147118 was highlighted as a cis pQTL associated with MATN3 levels and previously identified as a methylation QTL. This association strongly positioned it as a significant finding related to the regulation of the MATN3 protein.
title: Genetic and epigenetic architectures of neurological protein biomarkers in the Lothian Birth Cohort 1936

finding: In the study, the SNP rs144223596 (c.4510C>T) in the gene COL6A3 was identified as a significant mutation related to osteoarthritis (OA). The mutation led to decreased binding between collagen type VI (COLVI) and fibronectin, resulting in an osteoarthritic chondrocyte state. Additionally, when subjected to hyper-physiological mechanical loading, it was noted that aberrant function of the pericellular matrix (PCM) due to this mutation abolished the typical upregulation of PTGS2, which encodes cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2), indicating a failed inflammatory response crucial for chondrocyte health.
title: A high-impact COL6A3 mutation alters the response of chondrocytes in neo-cartilage organoids to hyper-physiologic mechanical loading

finding: The SNP rs3136249 was identified as a causal variant influencing both age at menarche (AAM) and age at menopause (ANM), with a posterior probability of 0.92 for its involvement in both phenotypes. This SNP was located in the intronic region of the MSH6 gene, which is recognized for its role in DNA mismatch repair and had previously been associated with ANM in another study. The findings suggest that this SNP could reflect a genetic underpinning for the timing of reproductive events in women.
title: Integrating Genome-Wide Association and eQTLs Studies Identifies the Genes Associated with Age at Menarche and Age at Natural Menopause

finding: The gene ACP1, located near rs2867125, was identified as a positive hit by the high-throughput screen used in the study, indicating its potential role in influencing BMI.
title: A multi-component screen for feeding behaviour and nutritional status in Drosophila to interrogate mammalian appetite-related genes

finding: The gene RBJ, situated near rs713586, was scored positively by the screen, highlighting its significance in the context of the related phenotype.
title: A multi-component screen for feeding behaviour and nutritional status in Drosophila to interrogate mammalian appetite-related genes

finding: This SNP was relevant in glucose metabolism representation.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: This SNP was associated with pancreatic cancer, suggesting its involvement in cancer susceptibility.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: This SNP in the CPS1 gene was associated with 11 metabolites related to glycine and glutamine conjugates, further emphasizing its impact on metabolic processes.
title: Genome-microbiome interplay provides insight into the determinants of the human blood metabolome

finding: This missense variant was linked to metabolite levels of mannose and 1-carboxyethyl-valine, which are associated with risk factors for type 2 diabetes and Crohn's disease.
title: Genome-microbiome interplay provides insight into the determinants of the human blood metabolome

finding: The SNP rs7589901 served as the lead eQTL for both the gene PAX8 and its associated antisense RNA PAX8-AS1. Its association indicated a potential link to tumor development, particularly in connection with cancer susceptibility loci.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: The SNP rs10175462 was in high linkage disequilibrium with rs7589901 and associated with cancer susceptibility, suggesting an intricate role of the PAX8 and PAX8-AS1 genes in cancer and possibly cardiac regulation.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: The SNP rs4848320 was linked to leukemia susceptibility, associated with the same context as rs10175462, reinforcing the connection between these variants, antisense RNAs and their roles in gene regulation in cardiac tissues.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: The SNP rs11888559 was identified in the 3' UTR of the CYP20A1 gene and it was associated with height in Filipino women. The global FST for this SNP was 0.36, indicating significant differentiation among populations, specifically between East Asian (CHB), European (CEU), and ancient African (YRI) populations, with derived allele frequencies (DAFs) of 0.81 and 0.95 in CHB and CEU respectively.
title: Origin of a novel CYP20A1 transcript isoform through multiple Alu exaptations creates a potential miRNA sponge

finding: The SNP rs7577078 was found within Alu elements in the CYP20A1 gene's 3' UTR. It displayed high derived allele frequencies (DAFs) across East Asian, European, and ancient African populations, indicating its relevance in differentiating these groups.
title: Origin of a novel CYP20A1 transcript isoform through multiple Alu exaptations creates a potential miRNA sponge

finding: The SNP rs849563, related to the Neuropilin-2 gene, was associated with susceptibility to autism in the Iranian population. This finding aligned with the hypothesis that dysregulation of Nrp2 might contribute to the pathogenesis of autism spectrum disorders and that Nrp2 polymorphisms have clinical relevance in ASD cases. The identification of this SNP highlighted its potential role in the mechanism underlying interneuronopathies linked to autism.
title: Dysregulation of Neuropilin-2 Expression in Inhibitory Neurons Impairs Hippocampal Circuit Development Leading to Autism-Epilepsy Phenotype

finding: The study identified rs10495582 as a significant SNP associated with high-altitude essential hypertension. This finding was contextualized within the population living at high altitudes, where higher diastolic blood pressure levels were observed, especially among populations like Aryans and those in Sakti. The SNP's link to hypertension contributed to understanding the physiological adaptations and health challenges faced by high-altitude dwellers.
title: A sneak peek at the high altitude adaptation of the Ladakh populations

finding: The I648T variant (rs759271255) was predicted to significantly disrupt protein stability and function of the STAT1 gene, contributing to potential immune system dysfunction.
title: Integrating Artificial Intelligence and Bioinformatics Methods to Identify Disruptive STAT1 Variants Impacting Protein Stability and Function

finding: The V642D variant (rs752542806) was identified as one of the six pathogenic variants that destabilized the STAT1 protein, which is associated with various body pathologies including immune system dysfunction.
title: Integrating Artificial Intelligence and Bioinformatics Methods to Identify Disruptive STAT1 Variants Impacting Protein Stability and Function

finding: The R602W variant (rs1209841496) disrupted protein stability and function of the STAT1 gene, which is crucial for immune regulation and could lead to immune system issues.
title: Integrating Artificial Intelligence and Bioinformatics Methods to Identify Disruptive STAT1 Variants Impacting Protein Stability and Function

finding: The L600P variant (rs137852678) was found to significantly destabilize the STAT1 protein, indicating its potential role in contributing to immune-related diseases.
title: Integrating Artificial Intelligence and Bioinformatics Methods to Identify Disruptive STAT1 Variants Impacting Protein Stability and Function

finding: The I578N variant (rs767475430) was predicted to disrupt the stability of the STAT1 protein, aligning with known pathologies of immune system dysfunction.
title: Integrating Artificial Intelligence and Bioinformatics Methods to Identify Disruptive STAT1 Variants Impacting Protein Stability and Function

finding: The W504C variant (rs916580554) was included among the six variants that significantly destabilized the STAT1 gene product, highlighting its importance in immune response.
title: Integrating Artificial Intelligence and Bioinformatics Methods to Identify Disruptive STAT1 Variants Impacting Protein Stability and Function

finding: The APOB_rs5742904_R3527Q variant was originally linked to familial hypercholesterolemia and was found to significantly increase levels of several cholesterol esters and other lipid species, accounting for approximately 18% of LDL-C variance (h2=0.68 vs 0.5 adjusted). This association was established in the Old Order Amish population.
title: Leveraging a founder population to identify novel rare-population genetic determinants of lipidome

finding: The SNP rs58964929 was classified as an introgressed reQTL affecting UBE2F responses to SARS-CoV-2 and influenza A, contributing to differences in immune response phenotype between Europeans and East Asians.
title: Environmental and genetic drivers of population differences in SARS-CoV-2 immune responses

finding: Located within the INPP5D gene, which is selectively expressed in microglia, this SNP has implications for Alzheimer’s disease.
title: A Semi-Supervised Ensemble Approach to Rank Potential Causal Variants and Their Target Genes in Microglia for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: This SNP was predicted to disrupt a MEF2 binding site in a microglia-specific enhancer located 28-kb upstream of the BIN1 promoter, indicating its role in influencing BIN1 gene expression related to Alzheimer's disease.
title: Single-cell epigenomic identification of inherited risk loci in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP disrupted a KLF4 binding motif in a microglia-specific putative enhancer 21-kb upstream of the BIN1 gene, which correlated with BIN1 gene expression, highlighting its relevance to Alzheimer's disease.
title: Single-cell epigenomic identification of inherited risk loci in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease

finding: This SNP was found to disrupt an oligodendrocyte-specific SOX6 motif, particularly in a peak interacting with the MAL gene, which is implicated in myelin biogenesis and function, thus associating it with the KCNIP3 locus.
title: Single-cell epigenomic identification of inherited risk loci in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP resided in a neuronal-specific intronic region within the KCNIP3 gene, with allelic imbalance indicating its functional alteration, although lacking a robust predictive significance from machine learning.
title: Single-cell epigenomic identification of inherited risk loci in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP was reported to disrupt a putative CTCF binding site near the TMEM163 gene, further suggesting a role in gene regulation in the context of Alzheimer's disease.
title: Single-cell epigenomic identification of inherited risk loci in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs1814432 was classified as a nonlinear dynamic eQTL for the gene CFC1B. Although specific details regarding its association to any particular trait were not provided, its classification as a nonlinear dynamic eQTL indicates its complex regulatory role, emphasizing the potential for varied effects across different stages of cellular differentiation.
title: Single-Cell Sequencing Reveals Lineage-Specific Dynamic Genetic Regulation of Gene Expression During Human Cardiomyocyte Differentiation

finding: The variant rs76647913 was associated with an introgressed haplotype on chromosome 10 that served as an eQTL for the nearby ATOH7 gene. ATOH7 is a circadian gene crucial for retinal ganglion cell development, influencing the ability to entrain circadian rhythms based on light stimuli.
title: Archaic Introgression Shaped Human Circadian Traits

finding: The SNP rs75804782 was linked to the largest chromosome 2 haplotype, which showed a strong association (R = 0.85) with chronotype among populations outside Africa, suggesting its role in shaping human chronotype in non-African populations.
title: Archaic Introgression Shaped Human Circadian Traits

finding: The variant rs61332075 exhibited the strongest latitudinal cline (R = 0.87) within a haplotype associated with chronotype, indicating its significance across non-African populations and its potential adaptive relevance.
title: Archaic Introgression Shaped Human Circadian Traits

finding: The EUR-specific variant rs35333999 caused a missense change in the PER2 protein (V903I), affecting its interaction with PPARG, a crucial regulator of lipid metabolism, and contributed to the adaptive regulation of chronotype.
title: Archaic Introgression Shaped Human Circadian Traits

finding: The variant rs62194932 was identified as an eQTL for the HES6 gene, which contributes to circadian regulation of LDLR and cholesterol homeostasis, further emphasizing the significance of this variant in the broader context of circadian biology.
title: Archaic Introgression Shaped Human Circadian Traits

finding: The interleukin 1 beta polymorphism rs16944 was identified as a significant genetic variant associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), suggesting it may influence inflammation processes related to the disease.
title: Identification of key genes and biological pathways in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The SNP rs4758 was identified as a significant cis-eQTL for the target gene PDIA6 in glioblastomas, with a Bonferroni-adjusted p-value of 1.30 × 10^-4. The alternative allele (T) was associated with higher PDIA6 expression levels compared to the reference allele (C). Mechanistically, rs4758 was found to enhance the binding affinity of transcription factor PBX1, which upregulated PDIA6 expression. In contrast, this eQTL effect was not significant in gliomasphere cells, indicating different regulatory dynamics due to lower PBX1 expression in this context.
title: Discovering single-cell eQTLs from scRNA-seq data only

finding: For the rs12467692 variant linked to UBE2E3, significant interactions with alcohol intake frequency were noted (p = 6.8 × 10^-6), underlining its potential role in BMI regulation via environmental factors.
title: Leveraging phenotypic variability to identify genetic interactions in human phenotypes

finding: The rs12996547 SNP showed an interaction with age (p = 1.8 × 10^-5) affecting TMEM18 gene expression, suggesting its influence on BMI mechanisms and age-related changes in adipose tissue.
title: Leveraging phenotypic variability to identify genetic interactions in human phenotypes

finding: Located at the 2p21 locus, variant rs12712928 was associated with glucose levels and type 2 diabetes risk. It mapped in a glucocorticoid-responsive chromatin site near the SIX2 and SIX3 genes, which showed glucocorticoid-induced expression. The variant had significant effects on enhancer activity and the risk allele was correlated with reduced expression of SIX2 and SIX3.
title: Glucocorticoid signaling in pancreatic islets modulates gene regulatory programs and genetic risk of type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs2122729 was associated with observations related to the browning of Alaska's boreal forest. This finding emerged from the study conducted in the context of forest health assessments near Fairbanks, Alaska, and reflected on the impacts of global warming on forest ecosystems, particularly focusing on tree damage from herbivores and environmental stressors.
title: Comparisons of Tree Damage Indicators in Five NASA ABoVE Forest Sites Near Fairbanks, Alaska

finding: The SNP rs6741499 was associated with both primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) and intraocular pressure (IOP). It was also reported in connection with the gene BRE, which was implicated in the disease, highlighting the SNP's relevance in the genetic landscape of POAG.
title: Retinal ganglion cell-specific genetic regulation in primary open angle glaucoma

finding: This variant was the most significant finding within the NDUFAF7 gene, associated with favorable exercise response phenotypes. Specifically, the T allele was linked to better exercise adaptations, as NDUFAF7 plays an essential role in mitochondrial complex assembly.
title: Identification of novel mitochondrial and mitochondrial related genetic loci associated with exercise response in the Gene SMART study

finding: The SNP rs17035364 was reported to be damaging based on Polyphen predictions, with a humdiv score of 0.990 and a humvar score of 0.674. Molecular dynamics simulations indicated that the RMSD values for this mutant protein were higher than those of the wild type, suggesting structural instability. The mutant showed greater compactness, with a radius of gyration mean of 46.05 A. The total energy ranged significantly higher than the wild type. This SNP was historically demonstrated to alter the structural function, underscoring its potential as a diagnostic marker and point toward possible therapeutic targets.
title: Insilico analysis of structural and functional impact of SNPs in Pleckstrin

finding: The SNP rs3816281 was predicted to be damaging with a humdiv score of 0.997 and a humvar score of 0.935. This mutation resulted in the highest degree of flexibility compared to the wild type, as indicated by RMSD and RMSF analyses. The total energy measurements taken from molecular dynamics simulations were significantly lower than that of the wild type. The mutation also showed a large range of intra-molecular hydrogen bonds, indicating greater flexibility in protein dynamics. Like rs17035364, this SNP was demonstrated to cause structural destabilization, aligning with its reported implications in potential therapeutic contexts.
title: Insilico analysis of structural and functional impact of SNPs in Pleckstrin

finding: The SNP rs6733839 was found to be causally implicated in the regulation of the AD risk gene BIN1 specifically in a microglia context. This finding suggests that genetic risk factors for Alzheimer's disease were linked to microglial cell types, highlighting their distinct regulatory mechanisms in relation to AD.
title: Neuronal and glial 3D chromatin architecture illustrates cellular etiology of brain disorders

finding: The SNP rs13030422 was associated with bladder cancer and related to the emerging roles of urine-derived components in the management of the disease, providing insights into the genetic factors involved in bladder cancer pathology as reported by Minkler et al. in 2021.
title: Establishment and Characterization of Novel Canine Organoids with Organ-Specific Physiological Similarity

finding: The SNP rs3749171 was identified as a protein-coding variant leading to the amino acid substitution T108M in the GPR35 gene. This variant was associated with an increased risk of ulcerative colitis (UC) and primary sclerosing cholangitis. Structural modeling studies suggested that this substitution might impact the activation capability of GPR35, and its relation to intestinal immune homeostasis was also considered significant, although the exact influence remained poorly understood.
title: Lysophosphatidic acid-mediated GPR35 signaling in CX3CR1+ macrophages regulates the intestinal cytokine milieu

finding: The SNP rs12474201 was associated with height, as identified by Wood et al. Its analysis in the SOCS5 locus suggested that while SOCS5 itself was not causal for height (P_MR=0.89), high expression of CRIPT was causally linked to high stature (P_MR=3.40×10^-09). Mutations in CRIPT are documented to be associated with short stature (OMIM:#615789), making this connection significant.
title: Mendelian Randomization integrating GWAS and eQTL data reveals genetic determinants of complex and clinical traits

finding: The SNP rs9076 was associated with neurofibrillary tangles measurement phenotype, having a remarkably significant p-value of 1.00E-12, suggesting its critical role in cognitive impairment related to Alzheimer's disease markers.
title: Systems genetics identifies the association between Enc1 and cognitive function in the hippocampus

finding: The SNP rs116172829 was associated with MEIS1, linked to the promoter of the gene STOM, and had a p-value of 8.19e-6 for prostate cancer association.
title: The PENGUIN approach to reconstruct protein interactions at enhancer-promoter regions and its application to prostate cancer

finding: SNP rs1130319 was linked to the alteration of the canonical polyA motif in the ADI1 gene, which impacted APA events, suggesting its regulatory effect on gene expression related to RNA processing.
title: Genetic Basis of Alternative Polyadenylation is an Emerging Molecular Phenotype for Human Traits and Diseases

finding: This variant, positioned near CD28, reduced T cell proliferation when targeted, illustrating its critical role in T cell activation pathways.
title: Linking candidate causal autoimmune variants to T cell networks using genetic and epigenetic screens in primary human T cells

finding: The SNP rs13010060 was associated with the genetic variations of the WT1 mutations specifically observed in Wilms tumor cell lines. This association provided insights into the distinct genetic backgrounds affecting the expression profiles of tumor cells derived from nephrogenic progenitor cells and more differentiated nephron cells, suggesting that this SNP may influence tumor development and characteristics in a manner linked to the early developmental origins of Wilms tumor.
title: Gene expression studies of WT1 mutant Wilms tumor cell lines in the frame work of published kidney development data reveals their early stem cell origin

finding: The SNP rs4952069 was found in the intronic region of CAPN14, a calcium-dependent cysteine protease influenced by Th2 cytokines IL-13 and IL-4. The study established a significant association with a p-value of 4.2 × 10^-6 related to enteric fever susceptibility. The findings suggested that variations at this locus might be linked to altered gene expression, potentially affecting individuals' susceptibility to enteric fever, due to its regulatory role in the oesophageal epithelium and its previous associations with allergic inflammatory diseases like eosinophilic oesophagitis and middle ear infections.
title: Genetic Susceptibility to Enteric Fever in Experimentally Challenged Human Volunteers

finding: The SNP rs11889341 was heavily prioritized in both EA and ha data, being a transition SNP with a ΔMGW of 1.75 Å. Its analysis underscored its priority based on SLE association in top SNP blocks.
title: Intrinsic DNA topology as a prioritization metric in genomic fine-mapping studies

finding: The variant rs72823641 was associated with asthma in multiple GWAS, showing very strong p-values between 4 x 10^-12 to 2 x 10^-136. It was mapped to a large intron of IL1RL1 and was used to identify a single candidate variant in linkage disequilibrium (LD), rs10173081.
title: DNA-binding factor footprints and enhancer RNAs identify functional non-coding genetic variants

finding: The variant rs10173081, which was identified in association with asthma, resided in myeloid-specific open chromatin and acted as an eQTL for multiple genes related to asthma. Its analysis showed predicted loss of binding for several transcription factors, including TCF21 and KLF3, which were previously associated with asthma risk.
title: DNA-binding factor footprints and enhancer RNAs identify functional non-coding genetic variants

finding: The intronic SNP rs10933431 in INPP5D was linked to lower protein levels of IDUA, suggesting a previously unreported relationship between this SNP and immune signaling pathways relevant to Alzheimer's disease.
title: Manifestations of genetic risk for Alzheimer’s Disease in the blood: a cross-sectional multi-omic analysis in healthy adults aged 18-90+

finding: The SNP rs934197 was identified as a strong association signal for low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels near the APOB gene, with a p-value of 5.1 × 10^-27 in a UK Biobank GWAS. FIVEx indicated that, while rs934197 showed strong associations with APOB expression in several tissues, it had low posterior inclusion probability (PIP) in subcutaneous adipose tissue, suggesting it was likely a shadow signal of another stronger eQTL. However, it presented the highest PIPs in tibial artery, esophagus, and sigmoid colon, indicating a potential causal regulatory role in those tissues.
title: FIVEx: an interactive multi-tissue eQTL browser

finding: The SNP rs4988235 in the MCM6 gene was associated with lactase persistence, indicating that the derived allele facilitated the ability to digest lactose. This finding was significant in relation to dietary habits and anthropological studies surrounding dairy intake.
title: Fast and accurate estimation of selection coefficients and allele histories from ancient and modern DNA

finding: The rs11883564 locus was associated with CD4+ T cell content in sun-exposed skin tissues, showing a p-value of 4.2 × 10−9. This finding also correlated with STAM2 gene expression, which is essential for T-cell development, and has been implicated in autoimmune responses such as alopecia areata.
title: Age, Sex, and Genetics Influence the Abundance of Infiltrating Immune Cells in Human Tissues

finding: The SNP rs3769821 was found to lead to a 30% reduction in luciferase activity when the risk allele was present, indicating reduced CASP8 expression. This reduction was consistent with decreased T cell killing of tumor cells, highlighting its association with breast cancer risk.
title: Pooled genetic screens identify breast cancer risk genes involved in evasion from T cell-mediated killing

finding: The SNP rs35349669 in the INPP5D gene was associated with late-onset Alzheimer's disease based on a replication study and meta-analysis. This finding suggested a genetic link between this polymorphism and the risk of developing Alzheimer's, a neurodegenerative disease implicated in social behavior deficits, aligning with the overall findings regarding TrkB signaling in the lateral septum and its associations with neurodegenerative conditions.
title: TrkB-dependent regulation of molecular signaling across septal cell types

finding: The SNP rs13020356 was associated with cancer cell growth, invasiveness, and stemness, specifically within the context of colon adenocarcinoma (COAD). This association was demonstrated through the research of Gelardi et al. (2021), which showcased how a selective competitive inhibitor of Aldehyde Dehydrogenase 1A3 impacted these cellular behaviors. The finding indicated that modulation of metabolic pathways through this SNP could influence tumor cell fate.
title: Targeting the cell and non-cell autonomous regulation of 47S synthesis by GCN2 in colon cancer

finding: The SNP rs1250229, located in the fibronectin (FN1) gene, was associated with a decreased risk of coronary artery disease specifically in patients with familial hypercholesterolaemia. This finding highlighted the potential protective role of the FN1 gene variant in cardiovascular health.
title: Conserved Cardiovascular Network: Bioinformatics Insights into Genes and Pathways for Establishing Caenorhabditis elegans as an Animal Model for Cardiovascular Diseases

finding: Alterations in FOSL2 binding due to rs10515944 were noted, with a direct association to Crohn's disease (CD). This points to its potential impact on Th17 responses relevant to this autoimmune condition.
title: The AP-1 factors FOSL1 and FOSL2 co-regulate human Th17 responses

finding: The SNP rs3116497 was shown to disrupt FOSL2 binding to DNA, which negatively impacted Th17 regulation, specifically linked to Crohn's disease (CD).
title: The AP-1 factors FOSL1 and FOSL2 co-regulate human Th17 responses

finding: The SNP rs13020216 was associated with the signaling pathway that mediates myeloma cell growth and survival, as detailed by Hideshima and Anderson in their 2021 study published in the journal 'Cancers'. This finding contributed to understanding the molecular mechanisms that underlie multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer.
title: Bioinformatics Illustrations Decoded by ChatGPT: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly

finding: This SNP acted as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) and exhibited a relationship with the expression levels of PIGF. It was highly linked to a Tibetan-enriched deletion, indicating its importance in high-altitude adaptation (HAA).
title: Characterization of Structural Variation in Tibetans Reveals New Evidence of High-altitude Adaptation and Introgression

finding: Similar to rs60199254, this SNP also served as an eQTL, showing a relationship with expression levels of TTC7A. Its link to a Tibetan-enriched deletion further emphasized its relevance in HAA.
title: Characterization of Structural Variation in Tibetans Reveals New Evidence of High-altitude Adaptation and Introgression

finding: The rs3002 locus was implicated in the formation of copy number gains (CNGs) during the process of re-replication in an experimental setup involving the his5 gene. In a strain background where the endogenous his5 was replaced with an ectopically integrated his5 gene next to the efficient origin at rs3002, a significant increase in resistance to 3-amino-triazole (3-AT) was observed, indicating that CNGs at this locus were likely promoting enhanced survival under selective conditions. The data from the qRT-PCR analyses supported that multiple copies of the his5 gene were acquired at rs3002, directly correlating the proximity of this origin to the changes in copy number and the frequency of CNGs.
title: Aberrant replication licensing drives Copy Number Gains across species

finding: The derived allele of rs4988235 was detected in the studied groups associated with adult lactase persistence, indicating that individuals carrying this allele could digest lactose in adulthood without symptoms. In the analysis, 1/3 of the individuals from the Hun period, 2 out of 14 from the Avar period, and 6 out of 31 from the Conqueror period carried this persistence allele. The presence of this allele was strongly linked to European ancestry, with all carriers predicted to have predominantly European ancestors.
title: Y-chromosome haplogroups from Hun, Avar and conquering Hungarian period nomadic people of the Carpathian Basin

finding: Similar to rs4988235, the derived allele of rs182549 was found in all studied groups related to adult lactase persistence. Notably, all carriers of this allele were heterozygous, with some carrying both derived alleles for rs4988235 and rs182549, while others carried just rs182549. The findings highlighted a strong correlation between the persistence genotype and European origin, particularly with all of the carriers linked to European mtDNA haplogroup H, suggesting potential historical admixture with non-carriers from East Eurasia.
title: Y-chromosome haplogroups from Hun, Avar and conquering Hungarian period nomadic people of the Carpathian Basin

finding: The rs55703767 variant in the COL4A3 gene was identified as a protective missense mutation (Asp326Tyr) associated with a reduced risk of diabetic kidney disease (DKD), including significant associations with various definitions of DKD such as any albuminuria and end-stage renal disease. It achieved genome-wide significance with an odds ratio (OR) of 0.79. The findings indicated that the protective effect of this variant was more pronounced in men and was dependent on glycemic control.
title: Genome-wide association study of diabetic kidney disease highlights biology involved in renal basement membrane collagen

finding: The rs12615970 SNP, located near the COLEC11 gene, was associated with chronic kidney disease (CKD) with a significant odds ratio of 1.31, indicating a potential involvement in DKD pathogenesis.
title: Genome-wide association study of diabetic kidney disease highlights biology involved in renal basement membrane collagen

finding: This SNP was associated with diabetic kidney disease, suggesting further investigation is warranted due to its previously noted associations.
title: Genome-wide association study of diabetic kidney disease highlights biology involved in renal basement membrane collagen

finding: The rs7588550 variant was found to be associated with CKD, further reinforcing the significance of loci implicating renal function.
title: Genome-wide association study of diabetic kidney disease highlights biology involved in renal basement membrane collagen

finding: This SNP demonstrated association with CKD extremes, highlighting its relevance in understanding the full spectrum of renal complications related to diabetes.
title: Genome-wide association study of diabetic kidney disease highlights biology involved in renal basement membrane collagen

finding: This variant in COL4A3 was associated with ESRD in African Americans with type 2 diabetes, indicating its potential role in diabetic kidney complications across populations.
title: Genome-wide association study of diabetic kidney disease highlights biology involved in renal basement membrane collagen

finding: The SNP rs6432901 from the SCN9A gene was significantly linked to GMD in the putamen, where individuals with the CC genotype showed lower values in the high pain sensitivity group. The interaction analysis confirmed significant effects between the SNP genotype and pain sensitivity (p=0.0259), supporting the notion that this SNP contributed to variations in pain perception through structural brain changes.
title: Genomic and transcriptomic profiles influence on brain morphology and their interactions with pain sensitivity individual differences

finding: The SNP rs35473199 from the SCN9A gene also showed significant relationships with the GMD of the putamen concerning pain sensitivity. Similar to rs6432901, CC individuals exhibited reduced GMD in high pain sensitivity individuals. The interaction was significant, with a p-value of 0.0292, indicating that this genetic variant, alongside others, modulated pain perception through its influence on brain structure.
title: Genomic and transcriptomic profiles influence on brain morphology and their interactions with pain sensitivity individual differences

finding: The SNP rs1260326 was identified as a potential causal variant in the GCKR gene for multiple biomarkers including glomerular filtration rate with a posterior inclusion probability (PIP) of 1.000, blood glucose level (PIP = 0.998), pulse rate (PIP = 0.823), and total protein level (PIP = 1.000). This finding indicated its importance in the genetically encoded coordination mechanisms between vital organs.
title: SparsePro: an efficient genome-wide fine-mapping method integrating summary statistics and functional annotations

finding: SNP rs2863957 in the 2q14.1 region showed significant association with functional connectivity traits, which are crucial for understanding brain connectivity patterns.
title: Common variants contribute to intrinsic functional architecture of human brain

finding: The rs59335482 insertion allele was positively associated with increased BIN1 mRNA expression in the brain. Furthermore, this increase was observed in the central nervous system of AD patients compared to non-AD patients, suggesting that while it is linked to higher expression, it does not correlate with an increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease, indicating a complexity in the functional consequences of this variant.
title: BIN1 protein isoforms are differentially expressed in astrocytes, neurons, and microglia: neuronal and astrocyte BIN1 implicated in Tau pathology

finding: The SNP rs74490912 showed a positive association with the expression of a specific BIN1 peptide (LQAHLVAQTNLLR), pointing to a potential link between this SNP and the expression of BIN1 at the peptide level. However, it held only weak linkage disequilibrium with the BIN1 AD variant rs6733839, indicating that while there was a finding of interest, its significance in the context of AD was limited.
title: BIN1 protein isoforms are differentially expressed in astrocytes, neurons, and microglia: neuronal and astrocyte BIN1 implicated in Tau pathology

finding: Identified as the lead variant in the SERPINE2 locus with the most significant association (p < 1×10<sup>-324</sup>), it was linked to a heightened risk of hypertrophic scars.
title: An expanded analysis framework for multivariate GWAS connects inflammatory biomarkers to functional variants and disease

finding: This variant was among those suggested causal in the SERPINE2 locus, correlating with risk for hypertrophic skin disorders.
title: An expanded analysis framework for multivariate GWAS connects inflammatory biomarkers to functional variants and disease

finding: Also identified as a putative causal variant in the SERPINE2 locus, showing significant association in relation to skin disorders.
title: An expanded analysis framework for multivariate GWAS connects inflammatory biomarkers to functional variants and disease
